Title: Burn: The Misunderstood Science of Metabolism
Author: Herman Pontzer
My Review:
This book is about newly emerging insights into human metabolism, and particularly the idea of 'constrained daily energy expenditure'. The take-home message is that the human body has evolved to expend roughly the same number of calories per day pretty much regardless of the level of physical activity (contrary to the old view that more activity resulted in more calories being burned). This has some important implications, for instance, it explains why exercise is ineffective for losing weight (dieting is better as it controls the energy INPUT). It also reframes the situation as one of trade-offs: if a body has a constant rate of energy expenditure, then introducing more physical activity means it has to expend less energy on other things. For instance, exercise reduces the inflammation response because the body has to divert its energy resources to muscles and other functions, reducing energy spent on unnecessary immune system activity.

Pontzer's writing is engaging and he regales the reader with stories of his time living among the Hadza hunter-gatherer tribe. The book also provides a crash course in evolution, paleoanthropology, diet science, and even dips into climate change at the end.

Title: Conquerors: How Portugal Forged the First Global Empire
Author: Roger Crowley
My Review: I really enjoyed the first half of this book - descriptions of the voyages of Bartolomeu Dias in finding a navigable route to the African Cape, and Vasco da Gama in reaching India's Malabar coast. The book gives good background on the justifications for wanting to reach India (i.e. to trade, spread Christianity, and seek out Prester John in Ethiopia), and it was interesting how the various voyages built upon each other, with Portuguese navigators getting further with each one. I found the second half of the book more slow going, with the various escapades of Almeida and Albuquerque, describing battle after battle in too much detail. That said, Crowley does give a good picture of the personalities of the major players at the time. It also would have been good to have more from the perspective of the African, Indian, Arabian, and Indonesian peoples who were forced to suffer the onslaught of Portuguese imperialism.

Title: The Motorcycle Diaries
Author: Ernesto Che Guevara
My Review: A retelling of the months-long trek across South America by Che Guevara and his friend Alberto Granado in the early 1950s. This has snippets of interesting insights and poetic prose, but is mainly filled with the bravado, privations, and close shaves of the young men's journey from Argentina to Venezuela. 'Motorcycle diaries' is a bit of a misnomer as their bike conks out fairly early on!

Title: The Underground Railroad
Author: Colson Whitehead
My Review:
Cora is a slave who escapes from her plantation in Georgia and is pursued across America by a slave catcher called Ridgeway.

Ostensibly this was a good story - a classic protagonist vs antagonist tale - but it wasn't an enjoyable read at all. Whitehead seems to make it difficult for the reader to keep track, and I was so glad when I found a summary on Sparknotes. The writing had a sort of detached, mythical nature, new chapters would begin without any explanation or context, lots of new characters seemed to be introduced at once, and I didn't understand a number of the references/specific vocabulary used. I also agree with other reviews which say that it lacked emotional punch (despite some of the horrific scenes described and alluded to).

Title: Mythos: The Greek Myths Retold
Author: Stephen Fry
My Review:
References to Greek mythology are always popping up, so I thought this would be a good introduction. Stephen Fry's erudition, wit, and humour certainly enhance this text, but still found it a bit of a slog.

The book is punctuated by lots of short stories retelling the various Greek myths, but there were so many names and references that it got a bit overwhelming at times. Example: "Amongst the many daughters of the Oceanid Doris and the sea god Nereus, was one Nereid called Galatea. ...she was adored by Polyphemus, a Cyclops. ...Polyphemus was the savage and ugly offspring of Poseidon and the Oceanid Thoosa."

I did get a better idea of the origin story though, i.e. how it started with the first order, Gaia and Ouranos, followed by Kronos and his children, then the Titanomachy, Zeus and Olympus, etc.

Title: The Odyssey
Author: Lara Williams
My Review:
Ingrid fritters away her days as an employee on a super cruiseliner, cycling from one job rotation to the next. The story is about the gradual uncovering of her past trauma (explaining her increasingly debauched behaviour whenever she gets Land Leave) as well as her relationship with the ship's captain Keith as she wins a place on his esoteric self-development 'programme'. Keith is a cult-like figure, obsessed with the Japanese philosophy of wabi sabi, and demands bizarre sacrifices from Ingrid as well as the rest of his staff.

The Odyssey definitely has similarities with the writing of Ottessa Moshfegh (debauchery, dysfunction, a female protagonist with a 'messy' life). The description of life on the ship was also quite Orwellian or Kafkaesque, and I think the book makes a statement about the vapidness and anomie-inducing nature of modern work culture (fitting in nicely with the wabi sabi ideas of "transience and decay").

I'm not sure if I understood the ending (or Ingrid's relationship with Keith for that matter), but this isn't the kind of book you read for a typical linear narrative.

Title: The Nordic Theory of Everything: In Search of a Better Life
Author: Anu  Partanen
My Review:
Finnish-born journalist Anu Partanen compares the lives of Finns and Americans across the areas of education, health, work, social security, and business. The idea underpinning the book is the ‘Nordic theory of love’. Contrary to misplaced notions that Nordic countries are socialist, this is a philosophy in which individuals are supported by the state so as not to be dependent on it or the other people around them; in other words, these countries bake in liberty from the moment their citizens are born by allowing their parents time off and equipping them with free education and healthcare.

The problem with comparing the USA to anywhere else is that it is an outlier to begin with. So of course the book tends to take the format of “look how bad life is in the USA… but look how much better it is in Scandinavia” (though Partanen does acknowledge that Nordic countries are far from perfect, and that the American outlook can have its advantages).

I was most interested in the section on education, for instance: how Finland reformed its education in the 1970s in anticipation of a knowledge economy; how it takes a supply- rather than demand-side approach to education (it’s a basic human right, not a good driven by demand); and how Finnish teachers are so well respected because of the sheer amount of training they have to undertake (700 hours of classroom practice during a master’s program). There were also interesting references to Beatrice Webb and the role of her idea of a “national minimum of civilised life” in founding Britain’s welfare state.

Altogether though, the book probably should have been cut by at least a third as it’s rather repetitive. There was also too much focus on America – this was necessary due to the comparison, but I felt like I finished the book wanting more insight into Nordic society and culture, not the societal ills of the USA (with which I’m already sadly well-acquainted).

Title: The Shadow of the Wind (The Cemetery of Forgotten Books, #1)
Author: Carlos Ruiz Zafon
My Review: This is the story of Daniel Sempere, a boy in mid-20th century Barcelona who unravels the life of the mysterious writer Julian Carax. I certainly didn't love this book but the gradual unveiling of the central mystery kept me interested enough to finish it. For me, the story was very complex and had so many different characters - if I put it down for a day or two I had to retrace my steps to remember what on earth was going on. The book is translated, but even so, the prose felt quite flat and I wasn't a fan of the dreamlike, pseudo-profound storytelling style.

Title: On Photography
Author: Susan Sontag
My Review:
On Photography offers some interesting nuggets of insight into the meaning and practice of photography... IF you are prepared to wade through the over-written and abstruse writing style.

Some points I took away: photographs are as much an interpretation of the world as paintings are, and exciting photos say something in a new manner; photography is an act of non-intervention - the photographer is a ‘supertourist’ or anthropologist who does not intervene in people’s lives but briefly visits them; how the advent of photography liberated painters from accurately describing reality, allowing them to focus on abstraction; photography is not a form of art all, but a medium through which art can be produced; the historical tendency towards black and white photography is because it was seen as more decorous than colour, or less sentimental and crudely lifelike (Cartier-Bresson renounced colour in his work).

Title: Photography Masterclass Creative Techniques of 100 Great Photographers
Author: Paul Lowe
My Review:
This was an interesting canter through 100 photographic 'masterpieces' split across 10 categories (e.g. places, things, ideas, stories, documents). Each section is chronological, containing images from the 1800s through to the early 2000s.

The book definitely improved my knowledge of notable photographers and also gave good insight into their thought processes. There were a few themes that came through for me. One is the idea that good photography involves the "art of observation" and "finding something interesting in an ordinary place" (Elliott Erwitt). It's about how you frame the world around you in a way that conveys a deeper meaning. Another theme was how gear is only a means to an end - that end being the ability to tell a great story. Also on this theme, the idea that photographers should know their equipment inside out and push it to its limits.

Some stand out bits for me included: Francis Frith and how he sold his grocery business to fund his travels around the world to take photos; how early photographers battled impressively against heavy equipment and the wet collodion process; John Davies' images of post-industrial Britain; Tony Ray-Jones' philosophy of taking photos of events that take longer to read than they do to happen; how Dougie Wallace uses flash to 'provoke' a situation and work with his street subjects rather than melt into the background; and finally Erich Salomon and the lengths he went to to sneak his camera into high society events, concealing his lens in a bowler hat or bagpipes!

Title: Posh Boys
Author: Robert Verkaik
My Review:
If you’re looking for a good read on the social iniquities of the private school system, this book isn’t it.

I read this because it was referenced in [b:Engines of Privilege: Britain's Private School Problem|40872550|Engines of Privilege Britain's Private School Problem|David Kynaston|https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/books/1541330107l/40872550._SY75_.jpg|63679359] as an interesting, more journalistic take on the issue. Unfortunately I just found Posh Boys too unfocused and repetitive.

The book is split in two: part one deals with the history of private schools from the medieval period onwards and annoyingly seems to have a particular focus on military figures (Verkaik has written on this topic previously).

Part two takes us into the modern era (up to 2017) but just seems to be an opportunity for the author to have his take on the events and characters of the day. We get mini biographies of figures like David Cameron, Nigel Farage, and Jeremy Corbyn, and discussion of Brexit, Cambridge Analytica, and the coalition government. The link with private schools is basically “all these terrible people went to private schools and therefore put personal ambition before national interest”.

There were some interesting insights: for instance how private school alumni can sign up for membership lists, giving them contact details for whenever they need advice or a handy internship; and Verkaik quotes the beginning of an article by Andy Beckett who writes humorously in the Guardian about the scourge of the Oxford PPE degree.

Title: Engines of Privilege: Britain's Private School Problem
Author: David Kynaston
My Review:
7% of children in the UK are educated at one of 2,500 private (‘public’ / ‘independent’) schools, where they benefit from approximately three times the level of resources available to their state-educated counterparts. This is ostensibly a service industry which creates an ‘educational apartheid’, ‘cements elite structures’, and is fundamentally ‘incompatible with the pursuit of a fairer, more cohesive society’.

This is the damning indictment of private schooling by academics David Kynaston and Francis Green. Across 9 chapters, the book examines the potted history of private schools and the enduring inertia of political will to reform them, what their fees actually buy, why parents choose to send their children to them, and detailed options for reform. The authors discuss the effects of extra resources, small class sizes, peer effects, and autonomy on attainment, and often return to the issues of charitable status and proposals to levy VAT (a policy still espoused by the Labour party on the eve of the 2024 general election).

The authors wear their stripes proudly in arguing for the need for reform, and there are some incisive and interesting points made. For instance, it’s often argued that parents should have a right to buy a private education if they so wish – that’s true of certain consumer goods and services, yes, but education is different because it’s ‘formative’ and has huge effects on life chances. There is also criticism of the idea that we can’t abolish private schools because that would leave a gaping hole in the economy – not so, because this assumes a counterfactual in which those parents, students, and teachers all disappear into the ether rather than join – and pay tax through - the state sector.

There is also discussion of how schools choose to justify their charity status through partnerships with state institutions. This is really laughable in many cases, for instance staff serving as governors at state schools, hosting joint debating clubs and drama events, and sharing swimming pools. All they have to do for their tax breaks is to pay lip service to the very idea of ‘public benefit’.

One strength of this book is its detailed proposals for reform. It discusses ideas to reduce both the demand for and supply of private education through contextual admissions policies (a form of positive discrimination), raising fees through taxation, and Open / Fair Access Schemes. Ultimately, though it’s likely that no major reforms will take place – and is it any wonder when one considers that the alumni of the accused extend like tentacles into all the high and influential positions in society?

I would recommend this book to anyone interested in the position of private education in contemporary Britain. The writing quality does vary across the chapters - there's a degree of repetition and over-quoting throughout (and an obsession with em dashes!), but the arguments and evidence are interesting.

Title: Yellowface
Author: Rebecca F. Kuang
My Review: Modern, zeitgeisty litfic - I really enjoyed this. Juniper Hayward steals the manuscript of her recently-dead, much-more-successful frenemy Athena Liu and turns it into a bestseller. But it's not long before accusations swirl and the immortality of her actions start to catch up with her. This is a very modern story about the pressures of the publishing industry, social media, and isolation. At the heart of the book is the question of authentic authorship; or, who is allowed to write what. It's interesting that Kuang is of Chinese heritage yet chooses to write from the first-person perspective of a white woman writing about Chinese history.

Title: Peacemakers: Six Months that Changed the World
Author: Margaret MacMillan
My Review:
After reading [b:The Sleepwalkers: How Europe Went to War in 1914|18669169|The Sleepwalkers How Europe Went to War in 1914|Christopher Clark|https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/books/1384804367l/18669169._SY75_.jpg|21905061], this seemed the logical next choice for understanding the political implications of the Great War. With great authority and detail, MacMillan takes the reader through the first six months of 1919 as the peacemakers (Wilson, Clemenceau, Lloyd George, and numerous national delegations) worked to hash out the Treaty of Versailles and various other peace deals. There is also a great deal of history and context discussed along the way.

Some of the key themes include: Wilson’s Fourteen Points and idea of self-determination as a guiding principle; the effect of Bolshevism and the desire for a ‘cordon sanitaire’ in Europe; France’s particular hatred towards Germany for having suffered the most; disagreements over reparations and the effect of these in the following decades; and the redrawing of maps and numerous conflicts of territorial claims (Italy and Yugoslavia, Germany and Poland, Japan and China, Greece and Turkey, the Sykes-Picot agreement for spheres of influence in the Middle East).

The only criticism I have is that I often finished a chapter feeling uncertain as to what the final outcome was – they wanted x, but the others wanted y… but what was the final result? There are a number of maps at the front of the book, but I didn’t find them totally clear.

Title: A Streetcar Named Desire
Author: Tennessee Williams
My Review: I decided to read this play because it seems to crop up quite often. Set in New Orleans, it's a story of desire, death, and madness swirling around three major characters: Stella, her husband Stanley, and her sister Blanche. There's so much tension, and what happens at the end is really shocking - both in terms of what happens to Blanche and Stella's reaction to it.

Title: Van Gogh: His Life & Works in 500 Images
Author: Michael   Howard
My Review: I thought this was a very good introduction to the life and works of Van Gogh. The first half covers his biography (the Lowlands and England, Arles, St-Remy, and Auvers), while the second half is a gallery dedicated just to his works. The whole book is replete with high quality colour images which, in the first part, also include some photographs and prints of other artists who served as Vincent's inspiration.

Title: Still Life
Author: Sarah Winman
My Review: After the first 50-or-so pages of this book I really wanted to put it down but was persuaded (by someone!) to continue. So I settled in for another 400 pages of trying-too-hard-to-be-eccentric, too-cool-for-speechmarks prose. I just didn't buy the characters or events - I didn't feel any emotional connection to them and things just seemed to happen for the sake of it. I also thought the book smacked of "I've been to Florence and I'm going to pepper every page with little Italian phrases and references to make it seem authentic".

Title: The Private Lives of the Impressionists
Author: Sue Roe
My Review:
This book covers the artistic trials and tribulations of the French impressionist painters between the 1860s and 1890s. The original members (Monet, Pissarro, Cezanne, Renoir, Sisley) met initially at the painting schools of Suisse and Gleyre, where they all aspired to exhibit at the elite galleries of the Salon (Manet was always thought of as the leader but never actually exhibited with them). The book follows the development of the group and its new members (Caillebotte, Morisot, Cassatt, Gauguin, etc) through their 8 exhibitions, dealing with historical events (the Franco-Prussian war, Haussmann's renovation), personal relationships, money worries, and artistic experimentation along the way.

I learned a lot here, though sometimes the writing felt a little unfocused (how could it not be when you're dealing with the private lives of so many different individuals). The book does contain colour plates of some of the artworks described, but a wider selection would have been appreciated.

Title: Demon Copperhead
Author: Barbara Kingsolver
My Review:
A heart-wrenching modern adaptation of David Copperfield, the book follows the ordeals and privations of Demon Copperhead as he navigates poverty, the care system, and addiction in Appalachia. Kingsolver's writing is vivid and immersive, and although the story's foundation is provided by Dickens, this retelling is very modern and very American in flavour (e.g. football, opioids, various other references that went above my head!). We root for Demon as he attempts to surmount the awful cards he's been dealt in life - to do so, he has to show tenacity, bravery, and compassion. An excellent, if long, read.

(I read this for a book group at work).

Title: The History Hit Miscellany of Facts, Figures and Fascinating Finds introduced by Dan Snow
Author: History Hit
My Review:
A little disappointed with this one as I expected more esoteric, lesser-known history facts. I get the idea and appeal of small doses of information too, but sometimes the lists and bullet points just felt lazy. Perhaps what would have been better is fewer facts given more time.

Some interesting things I remembered: the Romans' attitude to wearing trousers, the role of McDonalds during the end of Communism in Russia, mysterious medieval monsters, Syndrome K in an Italian hospital during WWII, societal consequences of the Black Death, the effect of Spanish flu on Woodrow Wilson's decision-making capacity at Versailles, the Isabella Stewart Gardner museum heist, and the breakdown of major Western artistic movements.

Title: Tory Nation: The Dark Legacy of the World's Most Successful Political Party
Author: Samuel Earle
My Review:
“Above all, Conservatism is the historic creed of Britain's ruling class”. Over 8 well-written chapters, Earle covers Britain's historical conservatism and ruling class hegemony, Tory flirtations with the far right, the role of the press, the Labour party's successes and (mainly) failures to gain power, and finally a blow-by-blow account of events between the Brexit referendum in 2016 and the chaos of Covid and beyond.

There were lots of interesting insights here: the intertwining of national identity and conservative viewpoints (making it difficult for Labour to challenge the status quo); the Tories' “fundamentally anti-democratic” bent (through support of hereditary institutions like the monarchy and House of Lords, opposition to voting reform); their ‘cult of common sense' that serves to legitimise ruling class interests without having to spell them out; anxiety induced by Britain's ‘fading superpower status' after WWII and scapegoating of immigrants and other groups; and how the Tories' austerity agenda plays directly into the ‘valorisation of hardship' (stiff upper lip, keep calm and carry on – again, key to national identity).

Clearly this is a book written by someone unsympathetic to the Tory project, though I found Earle's criticism - on both sides of the political divide - persuasive and even-keeled.

Title: Lessons
Author: Ian McEwan
My Review: Lessons is the lifetime-spanning story of Ronald Baines. The book contains strongly autobiographical elements, beginning in the '40s with Ronald's upbringing in Algeria and subsequent move to a boarding school in England. It then follows him into his '70s, ending with Covid. The main storylines are his relationships with two women in his life: his school piano teacher Miss Cornell, and later his wife Alissa - both ultimately negative, and both having rippling effects throughout his life. I found it quite difficult to get into this book as the writing is quite dense (and sometimes dreamlike), reminding me of Doris Lessing. The book really serves as a conduit for McEwan to recount and reflect on the major current affairs that took place during his life, particularly the Cold War and the fall of the Berlin wall (as well as some indulgent forays into Labour politics). I did enjoy the book more as the story progressed, but I think it represents a departure from the typical McEwan style that I enjoy.

Title: The Scout Mindset: Why Some People See Things Clearly and Others Don't
Author: Julia Galef
My Review:
This book contrasts two different mindsets: the soldier and the scout. A soldier engages in 'directionally motivated reasoning', (aka confirmation bias) according to their biases, prejudices, and identity. In contrast, a scout engages in 'accuracy motivated reasoning' in that they are more concerned with what is really true. Scouts are able to leave their identity at the door while they update their beliefs in the face of new evidence and conduct thought experiments to consider other perspectives (e.g. the double standard test, outsider test, conformity test, selective skeptic test, status quo bias test).

As someone who already thinks of themselves as having a scout mindset, I feel like I didn't learn many things from this book. Since reading about the philosophy of science (e.g. Karl Popper) and working in academia, I have always felt a sense of agnosticism about what is 'true', though I suppose I don't have a track record of engaging in thought experiments to try to 'disprove' my own beliefs, such as they are. Overall, I felt that this book relied a little too much on acecdata and I've have appreciated more discussion of the psychology research literature.

Title: Prophet Song
Author: Paul Lynch
My Review: Prophet Song is the story of an Ireland that descends into dystopia after an Emergency Powers Act is passed and everyday life gives way to tyranny. It focuses on Eilish Stack, a mother of four whose trauma is expressed deeply and viscerally as she battles to save her family. Excellent writing here, a sort of dark and atmospheric stream of consciousness style with very long paragraphs but not difficult at all to keep up with. I loved how how Lynch captured the gradual slide into totalitarianism and people's desperation to escape.

Title: The Forever Dog
Author: Rodney Habib
My Review: I read this as research before getting a dog. There are some useful insights here, but it took way too long to reach them. The tone of the book is overly 'chirpy' and the content is quite repetitive. As a UK-based reader I'm also not sure how well some of the things translate, e.g. concerning (lack of) regulation of dog food contents and presence of chemicals in certain products. But some interesting things included: dogs that live past 17 are known as 'Methuselahs'; dogs produce more pancreatic amylase than wolves (to digest carbs); dogs have little REM sleep, so need more overall sleep to compensate; dogs are sensitive to Schumann resonances (electromagnetic vibrations); 'core longevity toppers' can be added to dog food to promote health (e.g. many fruits and vegetables); and dog foods vary in how 'processed' they are.

Title: Lapvona
Author: Ottessa Moshfegh
My Review: Perplexing, grotesque, yet oddly engrossing (classic Moshfegh!). Lapvona is the story of a fictional medieval fiefdom somewhere in eastern Europe. Over a year it follows a handful of characters (Marek, Jude, Ina, Villiam) and touches on themes of guilt, religion, feudalism, and parenthood.

Title: The Ottomans
Author: Marc David Baer
My Review:
I read this because I realised after reading Christopher Clark's 'The Sleepwalkers' that I knew nothing at all about the Ottoman empire. In hindsight, this book was perhaps not the best one to choose, given that it covers too long a time period and only gets interesting in the last quarter.

Over 470 pages, Baer paints a picture of the the 'Ottoman Way' - an empire that was about 'incorporating others through religious conversion and tiered tolerance, ethno-religious plurality, and gendered social strata'. The empire went from strength to strength, being initially feared by other European powers in the C17, admired as a centre of culture and refinement in the C18, and finally looked down upon by other European colonial powers in the C19 as it declined. Interesting parts included discussions of Janissary units and the Collection, eunuchs, harems, fratricide, rivalries with the Habsburgs and later the Russians, and finally events leading up to WWI.

I learnt a fair bit from this book but generally I don't think it was very well written: too many asides going into too much detail, some amount of repetition, and sometimes little sense of the bigger picture. The maps were very helpful though the colour plates were a bit lacklustre.

Title: Endurance : Shackleton's Incredible Voyage
Author: Alfred Lansing
My Review: This was a good read that evoked the perils and hardships of Shackleton's ill-fated Trans-Antarctic Expedition of 1914-16. Based on interviews and diary entries, it was very detailed and at times made you feel like you were there. There were some points that dragged a little, however, and it would have been nice to know what happened to everyone afterwards, or people's reactions to the voyage back home.

Title: Great and Horrible News: Murder and Mayhem in Early Modern Britain
Author: Blessin Adams
My Review: This was an excellent read. I imagine that a career transition from police officer to history academic is fairly rare, but in this case it made for a very interesting perspective. Adams presents and dissects 9 different crimes during the 1600s. Each one is like a short story in the way it's written, but backed up by remaining documentary evidence. Above all, these stories provide insight into the social mores of the time, but also things like the first use of forensic evidence, the societal role of midwives, and church-sanctioned torture. The most prominent theme is that of suicide (or 'felo de se') - the early moderns had different ideas about suicide which carried its own sentence and had very negative social consequences for the remaining family (e.g. profane burial, forfeiture of estate). I knocked my rating down from 5 stars because quite a few of the examples were about suicide, and it'd have been nice to have a bit more variety. But overall this was extremely well written and very interesting.

Title: Howards End
Author: E.M. Forster
My Review: I found this quite a difficult read because often I had no idea what was going on (thank you, Sparknotes!). I suppose this is down to the modernist writing style and Foster's heavy use of ambiguity and symbolism. The novel has been summarised by the question "Who shall inherit England?"; it concerns the intermingling of three families who represent different social strata (the Schlegels, the Wilcoxes, and the Basts) and the passing down of a country house named Howards End (representing England).

Title: The History of Europe in Bite-sized Chunks
Author: Jacob F. Field
My Review: This was a good read. I've read history books about particular events and countries but this book does a good job of pulling them together and setting them in context. It really is easy to read and can be dipped into - my only criticism would be that I wish it didn't start in antiquity. Some specific things I learnt included: the run up to the Reformation (Johann Tetzel selling certificates of indulgence, Luther's angry reaction); more knowledge of the Habsburg empire, how it split into a Spanish and Austrian branch; and events around 1848 (German unification, Italy's independence from Austria).

Title: Matisse: Masters of Art
Author: Eckhard Hollmann
My Review: Turns out I don't care for Matisse. I didn't get a strong impression from this book about why his work is so celebrated. Involved in Fauvism (strong colours, simplified forms), something about reducing three-dimensional spaces into two, flat forms without shadows, then later moving to paper cut-outs. I don't understand from this book why he was a rival of Picasso as his work just looks childish and basic to me. The descriptions next to each work didn't do a lot to explain the actual art, and there were a few typos.

Title: This Is Your Mind On Plants: Opium—Caffeine—Mescaline
Author: Michael Pollan
My Review: This hasn't dented my appreciation of Michael Pollan and his work, but it was a bit of a lacklustre effort on behalf of the publisher. In this book, Pollan continues his adventures as a 'psychonaut' by experimenting with opium and mescaline (and going cold turkey with caffeine). The opium chapter is just a reprint of an essay he wrote in the 90s and centres around some arcane legal loophole in America about buying and growing poppies but not 'with intent' to harvest opium. The second chapter on caffeine was the best, delving into the history of the little bean and its effect on the Enlightenment. What he wanted to do with mescaline in the final chapter was ruined by the covid lockdown (why didn't they just wait so he could do it justice?). As always though, his writing is incisive and articulate and there were some interesting things to be learnt here.

Title: The Sleepwalkers: How Europe Went to War in 1914
Author: Christopher   Clark
My Review: All I knew about WWI was that it all kicked off when someone called Gavrilo Princip assassinated Franz Ferdinand (a vivid memory from KS3 history there!). Before reading this, I had also read The Trigger by Tim Butcher which provided some colour to the pencilled sketch of Gavrilo that I had in my mind. The Sleepwalkers is a big fat history book about the causes of WWI that is extremely well-researched and articulately argued. Apparently there is still debate about Germany's culpability in igniting the conflict (its imperial ambitions, the 'blank cheque' it gave to Austria-Hungary, the 'Fischer thesis' from the 1960s), but Clark argues against this by examining the evidence and framing Germany as but one of a number of imperialistic and paranoid European powers at the time. There is a LOT of information in this book and a huge cast list which was definitely confusing at times. But it's a confusing and complex story, so some work is required on behalf of the reader to persevere and supplement the book with multiple Wikipedia searches!

Title: Falling Angels
Author: Tracy Chevalier
My Review: Pretty disappointing. A story about two families, the Waterhouses and the Colemans, and their children at the turn of the 20th century in London. The main plot is about Kitty Coleman's promiscuity and gradually increasing involvement in the Suffragette movement. It was a pretty easy read as chapters were short and told from different characters' perspectives. But it just felt a bit jumbled and unfocused to me.

Title: Rules of Civility
Author: Amor Towles
My Review: A story set in 1938 New York - working class friends Katey Kontent and friend Evelyn Ross vie over the affections of rich banker Tinker Grey after a chance encounter. The main preoccupation of the novel is whether Katey and Tinker will ever get together, as Katey seeks the affections and auspices of Society People to better her position. I enjoyed the first half of the book but afterwards it just seemed chaotic with the number of new characters introduced. I don't think any of the characters were particularly convincing either, with all the overly slick and wisecracking dialogue.

Title: The Sense of an Ending
Author: Julian Barnes
My Review: "What you end up remembering isn't always the same as what you have witnessed". I enjoyed this short book as the writing style reminded me of Ishiguro and McEwan. Tony Webster reflects on his life from his school and university days, and particularly his tumultuous relationship with fellow student Veronica. It all centres on the fallout of their breakup and Veronica's subsequent relationship with Tony's friend Adrian. I must admit that I didn't understand the ending and had to look it up. I also I don't really see how it's about misremembering, as the significant events took place while Tony was not around anyway. The 'sense of an ending' I wanted was to better understand Veronica's character.

Title: The Dictionary of Lost Words
Author: Pip Williams
My Review: This is a story set in the ate 1800s about the creation of the first Oxford English Dictionary. Esme grows up in Oxford with her father who is part of a cadre of crusty, male lexicographers who compile word meanings in a glorified garden shed. It follows Esme through her boarding school years, first romance, dalliance with the Suffragette movement, and the first world war. The main aim of the book is to give a female voice to word meanings, as Esme starts to collect slang words from a range of female characters. The book is based on reality, with details of the lexicographical work and some of the characters being true to life. It sounded like such a good idea, but I found it dragged on too long.

Title: Modern Art 1851-1929: Capitalism and Representation (Oxford History of Art)
Author: Richard R. Brettell
My Review: I was so excited to read this but I've realised now that the Oxford History of Art series is written for people who already know about art. This is not me. I don't feel like I learnt anything at all from this book because its writing was too highbrow and most of the time the author just dropped in names and references instead of talking about any one thing in depth.

Title: Sea of Tranquility
Author: Emily St. John Mandel
My Review: A time-bending narrative connecting disparate characters between 1912 and 2401. This reminded me of an Anthony Doerr novel - it took a little while to get going, but it was worth it when the different storylines started interacting. I enjoyed the writing, which had a nostalgic or even melancholy feel to it.

Title: The Trigger: The Hunt for Gavrilo Princip: The Assassin Who Brought the World to War
Author: Tim Butcher
My Review: I really enjoyed this! Tim Butcher strikes again with his unique blend of history, memoire, and travel writing. This time he retraces the steps of Gavrilo Princip, the man who assassinated archduke Franz Ferdinand and unknowingly set off a chain of events that resulted in the Great War. The book is extremely well researched and well balanced, and Butcher even discusses a novel historical source in the form of Princip's school records.

Title: The Paris Apartment
Author: Lucy Foley
My Review: Very silly but good for a holiday read.

Title: Impressionism: Masters of Art
Author: Florian Heine
My Review: This is a really good, short introduction to the impressionism movement in painting which emerged in Paris in the late 19th century. It has a short introduction to the movement before delving into the works of Monet, Manet, Renoir, Degas, Cassatt, Merisot, and Caillebotte, Pissarro, and Sisley. The works are well albeit briefly explained - I'd just have liked more!

Title: Purple Hibiscus
Author: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
My Review: This book has really heavy subject matter and so wasn't a very fun read. Set in early 2000s Nigeria, it's about brother and sister Kambili and Jaja, their mother, and their abusive Catholic zealot father Eugene. Eugene is a 'big man' who metes out horrific violence on his family and has utter disdain for his non-Catholic father and wider community. The story is told from Kambili's perspective, and is about her increasing awareness of the world around her as she spends time with her aunt and cousins in Nsukka. The backdrop to the story is political unrest (Eugene's newspaper is shut down by the government) but also fuel shortages and pay disputes - to the extent that auntie Ifeoma emigrates to the US. I love Adichie's other works but this one felt like hard work.

Title: Breasts and Eggs
Author: Mieko Kawakami
My Review: This story (though probably the wrong word) centres around the world of 30-something writer Natsuko, as well as her sister Makiko, and Makiko's daughter Midoriko. Ultimately, it's about Natsuko's desire to have a baby and raise it on her own without a father. For the most part, men are background characters in this book - a deadbeat father, Midoriko's boyfriend who only exists through photos. Many pages are dedicated to Makiko's obsession with breast augmentation surgery, followed by Natsuko's research on artificial insemination. I suppose the book can be taken as a critique on Japan's patriarchal society, but the characters didn't seem to be feminists or anything.

Title: Africa Is Not A Country: Breaking Stereotypes of Modern Africa
Author: Dipo Faloyin
My Review:
3.5 stars. "For too long, ‘Africa' has been treated as a buzzword for poverty, strife, corruption, civil wars, large expanses of arid red soil where nothing but misery grows." Faloyin attempts to break some of these stereotypes by taking the reader through the Africa's colonial history (e.g. the Berlin Conference of 1885), considering the Western view of Africa (white saviour complex, Live Aid, depiction in cinema), and ending with some positive examples of activism and leadership.

It's quite literary or discursive for a non-fiction work, and I wasn't a fan of the writing style (e.g. - "Just wait, and amid the forward progression of the Great Everything, each country's station in life will present itself - if purpose can locate opportunity, and hope finds a way of cohabiting with reality."). That said, there are lots of interesting points here.

Title: The Invention of Nature: The Adventures of Alexander von Humboldt
Author: Andrea Wulf
My Review: This book tells the interesting life story of Prussian scientist and grandfather of ecology, Alexander von Humboldt. It covers a generally interesting time period (French revolution, Napoleonic wars, South American independence) and characters along the way (Charles Darwin, Simon Bolivar, Goethe, Thoreau, etc). There are even an additional three chapters after Humboldt's death describing how others were influenced by him (George Marsh, Ernst Haeckel, and John Muir). The book has obviously been thoroughly researched with plenty of quotations from journals, letters, and other publications (the last third of the book is just end notes!). It was a mostly interesting read, but got a little repetitive and sometimes too mired in the detail.

Title: The Photograph (Oxford History of Art)
Author: Graham Clarke
My Review:
This was my first taste of the Oxford History of Art series.

The good: I learnt about some interesting photographers like Diane Arbus, Chris Killip, Martin Parr, Brassaï, André Kertész, and Ernst Haas. There was a range of different photographic styles and sometimes the interpretation/criticism helped to explain what makes photos 'good'.

The bad: the writing style! A few snippets: "Phenomenologically, there is a primary concern with the thingness of things", "...a complex typology as to how space is suggestive of the mythology of possibility and freedom, and historical and sociological realities", and "The image is concerned with the quizzical nature of presence". Also, the book focuses heavily on black and white photography, and most of the works are somewhat dated (the book was published in 1995 but even so, most examples were from the early to mid 20th century).

Title: Exercised: The Science of Physical Activity, Rest and Health
Author: Daniel E. Lieberman
My Review: This wasn't a particularly great read, though it sounded so interesting. The book is predicated on the fact that humans didn't evolve to exercise, which is why we find it hard to find time for. I think there's too much time spent on the evolutionary history of homo sapiens and comparisons with hunter-gatherers - we get it, we're WEIRD, now please just focus on the science. There were some interesting things like how sedentariness causes inflammation, how muscles work, how physical activity is measured/quantified, but these tidbits were too few and far between.

Title: The Paying Guests
Author: Sarah Waters
My Review: Set in 1920s London, this is the story of a mother and daughter who take on two lodgers to avoid slipping further into debt, and of the illicit relationship that ensues between the daughter and one of the lodgers. Had there been some kind of irresistible intrigue, unsolved mystery, or unexpected twist this book may have merited its 600 pages. But there was not. And it did not.

Title: Exciting Times
Author: Naoise Dolan
My Review: Exciting Times is the story of 22-year-old Ava who moves to Hong Kong to teach English as a foreign language. It centres on Ava's romantic relationship with Julian, an emotionally neutered banker, and subsequently with Edith, a junior lawyer, with power dynamics and sexuality being key themes. The writing style is sardonic and wry, and replete with references to text messages and Instagram. It was an interesting read because of its setting, but Ava's frenetic machinations and incessant self-loathing leave a bit of a bitter taste.

Title: Bullshit Jobs: The Rise of Pointless Work and What We Can Do About It
Author: David Graeber
My Review: I enjoyed this, partly because like many people, I have elements of bullshit in my own job (though would stop short in describing my whole job as bullshit!). The best part of the book was the first half which includes testimonies from people with bullshit jobs, as well as a typology (flunkies, goons, duct tapers, box tickers, and taskmasters). Graeber then delves into some reasons for the rise of bullshit jobs but this felt a bit academic and desultory (in my opinion the concepts of spiritual violence, managerial feudalism, and social value weren't explained super clearly). I did enjoy the comparison of bullshit jobs to BDSM though (i.e. in both cases, both parties are engaging in make-believe but only in the latter case can one utter a safe word to make it stop!).

Title: Heaven
Author: Mieko Kawakami
My Review: 3.5 stars. This was a difficult read thanks to its heavy themes of bullying, depression, suicide, and nihilism, but these were countered by its brevity and easy-to-read prose. The 14-year-old unnamed narrator is bullied mercilessly for his lazy eye to the extent that he becomes somewhat disassociated from reality (there are some very upsetting scenes). He enters into an off-and-on friendship with fellow bullied classmate Kojima. I find it difficult to articulate, but there is a theme here about meaning. Kojima finds meaning in lots of things, including being bullied, and this view is contrasted with that of Momosa, one of the bulliers, who expresses his nihilistic worldview and utter rejection of any meaning at all. Once the bullying comes to a stop, the narrator gets corrective surgery for his eye and begins to see the world in a new way - perhaps this is a metaphor for the oppressive chokehold suffered by victims of bullying.

Title: Geography: Ideas in Profile
Author: Danny Dorling
My Review:
Not impressed with this at all. I thought it would be an overview of the academic field of geography. I thought it would discuss key concepts, thinkers, and findings in the field. I thought I would learn about the tools geographers use to answer their questions. Instead, I got a meandering and jumbled 'report card' on the world's big issues as of 2016 (especially climate change).

At the end they say this: "Indeed, geography may appear to cover every subject. Yet, this is what makes geography so important: it is the enabling subject. It enables us to join physics with culture, biology with philosophy, and even zoology with architecture." What a shame the authors neglected to include any of those interesting topics here.

Title: The Canterbury Tales: A Retelling
Author: Peter Ackroyd
My Review: Having never attempted the original Canterbury Tales, I thought this would be a good introduction to its stories. I think what Peter Ackroyd has done here is brilliant, and I'm a fan of his historical (non-fiction) writing. However, I didn't actual enjoy the majority of the tales here as they were overly long, obsessed with religious and classical references, and mostly just dead boring. That said, I do appreciate a lot of the themes running through the tales, most of which are still relevant to today's society.

Title: The State of Africa: A History of the Continent Since Independence
Author: Martin Meredith
My Review: The majority of this book was a slog to read. I was hoping for more of a storytelling style, some analysis or synthesis of trends and events, and most importantly some insights into 'the state of Africa' since independence. Instead, I got dozens of mini case studies (or biographies of dictators) crammed with detail, with nothing to link them together. But then again, this would be difficult to achieve because Africa is a large continent with lots of things going on! Obviously there are lots of negative things to dwell on here: dictators, civil wars, corruption, racism, famine, etc, but I would have liked more on the positive side of things, especially as of 2011 when the book was published.

Title: War and Peace
Author: Leo Tolstoy
My Review: An epic tale following the Bolkonsky, Rostov, and Bezhukov noble families in Russia during the Napoleonic wars. There was a lot to appreciate in this story like Tolstoy's humanist/absurdist outlook on life, the search for meaning, and some of the relationships between the myriad characters. I don't think it's controversial to say that the 'War' parts are overly long and detailed and that the whole novel could have been 500 pages shorter. It was an easy read, though after 1,200 pages I really wasn't in the mood for the 100-page epilogue full of philosophical ramblings!

Title: A Short History of Ireland, 1500-2000
Author: John Gibney
My Review: Coming from a place of relative ignorance, this was an excellent primer on the history of Ireland. A quick glance at the Chronology section at the start shows a litany of grievances, rebellions, wars, famines, conflicts, and troubles - Ireland really has had it rough. I found it interesting how Britain actually exacerbated conflicts with its often heavy-handed response, and how Ireland formed alliances and solidarities with enemies of Britain (Spain, France, South African boers, and even Gaddafi). The book ends with the 1998 Good Friday Agreement, but I feel that it just skipped over it - I had to rely on Google completely for that one.

Title: The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society
Author: Mary Ann Shaffer
My Review: This is a post-war story about a woman who takes up an invitation to visit Guernsey to write about its experience of the German occupation. It's an interesting and original premise but unfortunately it's all told in an epistolary format. This made sense for the first part of the book where Juliet is receiving letters from the various members of the Literary Society, but I expected it to change to prose when she actually travelled to the island. The letter-writing just made it feel 2D to me, and the trailer for the film makes the story feel much more 'alive'. Not very much happens in the story (though its central plot is a romantic one), so in my opinion this provides all the more need for living, breathing prose to bring the characters and their stories to life.

Title: The Age of The Strongman: How the Cult of the Leader Threatens Democracy around the World
Author: Gideon Rachman
My Review: Through several vignettes of 'strongman' world leaders, this book describes trends in geopolitics within the last 20 or so years. I wasn't a fan of structure where each leader is covered in a separate chapter (they have so many commonalities that this felt repetitive). Really, the themes of the book are the rise of populism and the battle between democracy and autocracy, and more of a synthesis would have made it a better read (the epilogue just starts to provide this). You'd have to have been living under a rock for the last 20 years or be very ignorant of current affairs to not already know something about the majority of the leaders discussed here, though I did learn some things about Orban, Duterte, 'Amlo', and George Soros.

Title: The Color Purple
Author: Alice Walker
My Review: Celie is born into a life of racism, poverty, and abuse. She becomes separated from her sister Nettie and finds herself in a new - yet also abusive - relationship with her husband, the ominously named 'Mr -----'. There's great character development in this story told through Celie's prayers and her and Nettie's letters to each other. The story has so many layers - gender, race, sexuality, religion, etc, but I must admit that I found it a little difficult to read thanks to the consistent use of dialect and lack of traditional punctuation.

Title: Education in Britain: 1944 to the Present
Author: Ken Jones
My Review: This books covers the history of educational policy in the UK from 1944-2016. As a textbook, the writing is dense and hard-going, but there are some interesting insights to be had. The book covers a lot of material, dealing with a patchwork of reports, acts, and circulars, with dedicated sections for each of the four nations in every chapter. But it also discusses some of the underlying themes and motivations, and trends in educational policy. For me, one of the most interesting of these was the enduring legacy of the grammar school - how subsequent structural reforms always harked back to the 'good old days' of grammar schooling experienced by the vast majority of policymakers (despite early acknowledgement that they exacerbate social inequality). Another unavoidable trend is the role of globalisation, neoliberalism, and the knowledge economy on education throughout the decades, with schools moving from a child-centred approach (e.g. Plowden report) to data-, economic-, and market-driven principles (and the negative impact this had on teacher recruitment and retention). Lots of interesting things here, but you really have to work hard to wade through the writing.

Title: Less is More: How Degrowth Will Save the World
Author: Jason Hickel
My Review:
3.5/5. Degrowth is an approach in ecological economics which argues that we need to stop focusing on growth in order to live within planetary boundaries and create a more equal society.

The first part of the book lays out the history of capitalism and sketches out its worldview (enclosure, elite accumulation, artificial scarcity, exchange-value vs use-value - I found this the most interesting part). It also introduces a sort of philosophical schism between animist and dualist beliefs (e.g. Descartes' ideas of man's dominion over nature), and considers whether technology can save us from climate disaster (covering carbon capture, renewables, and the Jevons paradox).

The second part considers the (tenuous) relationship between GDP and human wellbeing (McKeown thesis, Easterlin paradox) and some alternative metrics like the Genuine Progress Indicator. After this comes the suggested pathway to degrowth: ending planned obsolescence, cutting advertising, shifting from ownership to usership, ending food waste, and scaling down industry. This section also deals with proposed solutions to the unemployment this would create, though not convincingly in my opinion. The final chapter was a strange amalgamation of things from previous chapters, spending a bit of time reconsidering animism.

This was an interesting read, though covers a lot of material in a short time, and I wish it had spent longer on concrete solutions than (sometimes repetitive) hand-wringing and vagaries.

Title: Small Things Like These
Author: Claire Keegan
My Review: A novella set in mid-1980s Ireland about a well-respected family man, Bill Furlong, who one day discovers a girl locked up outside by nuns on a freezing December night. The story is about his cognitive dissonance in accepting a bribe from the nuns in return for his silence and his subsequent actions. Although fictional, the story draws attention to the insidious 'Magdalen laundries' for 'fallen women' operated by the Catholic church across Ireland until the late 20th century. Excellent writing.

Title: Chasing the Devil: On Foot through Africa's Killing Fields
Author: Tim Butcher
My Review:
This was a good read, but I can't help comparing it to Blood River, which I read first. Chasing the Devil follows much the same format, this time retracing the steps of Barbara and Graham Greene as they trekked across Sierra Leone and Liberia in the 1930s. This time Tim is accompanied by travelmates David, Johnson, and Mr Omaru, and the book is much more introspective as he recounts his time in Liberia as a newspaper reporter.

Chasing the Devil employs the same mixture of travel writing and history, though the various coups and civil wars are hard to keep up with. Towards the end, the book delves briefly into the Poro secret jungle society and touches on the role of colonialism as a cause of the challenging state of many modern African countries (i.e. because Liberia was set up initially as a free country, yet nevertheless suffers untold problems). These issues I found most interesting, but got relatively little airtime.

Title: Girl With a Pearl Earring
Author: Tracy Chevalier
My Review: The Dutch Golden Age painter Johannes Vermeer painted 'Girl with a Pearl Earring' around 1665 with an alluring and photorealistic quality. It's easy to look into the girl's eyes and imagine who she might have been, where she came from, what her relationship was with the painter. This is exactly what Chevalier does with this story of Griet, a 16-year-old maid working in the Vermeer household in mid-1660s Delft. Griet is headstrong and intelligent, though inexperienced and naive, and finds herself increasingly and dangerously close to the painter as she becomes his assistant. The book is well written, and the prose is easy to follow (if a little '2D' at times). I liked the symmetry with the repeated motifs of the spinning knife and the right-pointed tiled star at the beginning and end of the novel.

Title: Pablo Picasso 1881-1973: Genius of the Century
Author: Ingo F. Walther

Title: McGlue
Author: Ottessa Moshfegh
My Review: This was like a fever dream full of blood, bile, and booze. McGlue is an alcoholic 19th century sailor who is awaiting trial for the murder of his friend (/lover?) Johnson. Thanks to his love of the bottle and an unhealing gash in his head, McGlue has trouble recollecting the night in question and spends his time in prison teetering on the edge of reality. The writing reminded me of Blood Meridian, and I'm so glad that Moshfegh doesn't write like this any more.

Title: Death in Her Hands
Author: Ottessa Moshfegh
My Review: I enjoyed this, and it was a quick and easy read. The story of Vesta Gul, a widow living a lonely and isolated life in New England with her canine companion. She finds a note about a supposed murder and her brain (or 'mindspace') just goes wild, inventing characters and theories. The somewhat shocking ending suggests presence of mental illness (perhaps dementia). The writing is great here - the reader is totally enveloped in Vesta's machinations and it becomes increasingly difficult to tell fact from fiction as the story reaches its end.

Title: Man's Search for Meaning
Author: Viktor E. Frankl
My Review:
This was a nice little read, quite uplifting and inspirational (words I never use in reviews!). Frankl retells his experiences of surviving Auschwitz as a way into logotherapy, his life's work and contribution to psychotherapy. The ideas of the book are best summed up with Nietzsche's quote: "He who has a why to live for can bear with almost any how". Frankl gives examples of how meaning made everyday life in the concentration camp bearable, i.e. curiosity, humour, cultivating one's mind, and clinging to 'shreds of hope'. There are definitely strong crossovers with Stoicism here, as finding meaning in suffering is also a key theme.

Frankl lists three ways to discover the meaning of one's life: (1) by creating a work or doing a deed; (2) by experiencing something or encountering someone; and (3) by the attitude we take toward unavoidable suffering. I also found the idea of 'tension' interesting, i.e. that there is/should be a continuous mismatch between one's present and future self (things you want to become, things you want to do, etc) as this drives a person to find meaning and do things.

Title: Cry of the Kalahari
Author: Mark  Owens
My Review: The fascinating story of Mark and Delia Owens, two American PhD students who spend seven years in the Kalahari desert in the 1970s conducting ecology research on lions and brown hyenas. At times the book felt like fiction, with a range of interesting characters and events.

Title: The Portable Veblen
Author: Elizabeth Mckenzie
My Review: Kooky and fun!

Title: Atlas Obscura: An Explorer's Guide to the World's Hidden Wonders
Author: Joshua Foer
Additional Authors: Ella Morton, Dylan Thuras, Atlas Obscura
My Review: A (mostly) fascinating collection of the world's lesser-known sights. I found the section on the US a little bit dry, but otherwise there were some really cool places in here. I particularly liked the little boxes which talked about collections of things, e.g. Conlangs, epic film sets you can visit, and Australia's big things. Excellent coffee table book material!

Title: Cold War: For Forty-Five Years the World Held Its Breath
Author: Jeremy Isaacs
My Review: An excellent introduction to the Cold War and to the MADness that is Mutually Assured Destruction. This book was very readable and is set out a bit like a textbook, with images and breakout boxes. I also liked how it wasn't strictly linear but rather discussed 'episodes' which overlap chronologically with other events discussed elsewhere.

Title: Homesick for Another World
Author: Ottessa Moshfegh
My Review: This series of bizarre short stories seemed like 'classic Moshfegh' (if that exists already!): irreverent, insalubrious, and grotesque characters living in the margins of society. I did feel a sense of disappointment at the abrupt ending of most stories, but something kept me going.

Title: The Vanishing Half
Author: Brit Bennett
My Review:
A story about twins in 1960s Bible belt America who run away from their home town and eventually become separated from each other too and lead very different lives.

Mixed feelings about this one. The good: a longitudinal narrative focusing on different characters and how their paths cross over time. The bad: I struggled a bit with the premise, i.e. the idea of being black but passing for white - "When she'd first passed over, it seemed so easy ...", "She'd walked in a colored girl and left a white one. She had become white only because everyone thought she was." It also felt a little long and the ending wasn't very satisfying.

Title: The Murder of Roger Ackroyd (Hercule Poirot, #4)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review: Bit of a damp squib, this one. A complex storyline, a myriad of rather 2D characters, and an underwhelming conclusion.

Title: How Soon Is Now? The Madmen & Mavericks Who Made Independent Music (1975-2005)
Author: Richard King
My Review: This book is intended to be a 'survey' of independent music labels between 1975 and 2005. It covers Postcard, 4AD, Creation, Warp, Mute, Domino, and (mainly) Rough Trade, which signed artists like Joy Division, The Smiths, Depeche Mode, Sonic Youth, Dinosaur Jnr, Oasis, Moby, the Strokes, the White Stripes, and the Arctic Monkeys.  I think the major flaw of this book is its focus and framing around the record labels themselves. I found that side of it really boring and I wanted more insight into the evolution of the music industry and the battle between 'majors' and 'indies'. There was some interesting history about, e.g. the Madchester scene and the hacienda, Britpop, and the threat posed by online sharing in the early 2000s, but too much about the label founders. About 75% of the writing is just direct quotation as well, which grated on me.

Title: Blood River: A Journey to Africa's Broken Heart
Author: Tim Butcher
My Review: "In six harrowing weeks of travel I felt I had touched the heart of Africa and found it broken." This was a throughly excellent read about a war correspondent retracing the steps of Victorian explorer H. M. Stanley along the Congo river. It's a perfect blend of travel writing and history.

Title: Heart of Darkness
Author: Joseph Conrad
My Review: A difficult read due to the density of the writing and general lack of clarity as to time and space (I relied on Sparknotes for help!). But was also very evocative and, as the name suggests, dark. I read this in conjunction with Blood River by Tim Butcher who, incidentially, wrote the introduction to this edition of Heart of Darkness.

Title: Regeneration (Regeneration #1)
Author: Pat Barker
My Review: What a letdown. A story based on the treatment of shell-shocked soldiers at Craiglockheart hospital in 1917, including Siegfried Sassoon and Wilfred Owen. I'm amazed how such interesting story fodder could translate into such a slow and boring book.

Title: The Education Debate (Policy and Politics in the Twenty-First Century)
Author: Stephen J. Ball

Title: Tender is the Flesh
Author: Agustina Bazterrica
My Review: I took a risk with this book as it's not the kind of thing I usually read. The risk did not pay off. It's set in a dystopian future where all animals have been infected with a mysterious virus, which apparently necessitates the breeding of humans for protein. Why this is the obvious or default option is never explained, and there's generally a lack of depth. It follows the perspective of a man who works in a 'special meat' processing plant who, although undergoing trauma, is utterly detestable. The writing was quite poor (it didn't adhere to the 'show, don't tell' school of thought), though this might be due in part to the translation. Contrary to what lots of reviewers say, I don't think the ending was THAT shocking, and I could see it coming near the end.

Title: The Member of the Wedding
Author: Carson McCullers
My Review: A story set in the American deep south on the cusp of the end of WWII about a girl trying to figure out her place in the world. I love McCullers' writing and her way of depicting the psyches of and interactions between different characters.

Title: The Winter of Our Discontent
Author: John Steinbeck
My Review: I struggled with this one. I love Steinbeck but I found this book difficult to understand in parts thanks to the seemingly odd language employed (especially in dialogue). To me, parts of it felt like some kind of fever dream where one sentence has no logical connection to the next. It was only at the end when things came together that I really got a sense of the story. I also think the book has a poorly written synopsis.

Title: Renewable Energy: A Primer for the Twenty-First Century (Columbia University Earth Institute Sustainability Primers)
Author: Professor Bruce Usher
My Review: This was an absolutely brilliant primer on renewable energy and actually made me feel hopeful for the future. It's structured really well, beginning with energy transitions of the past (wood to coal, to nuclear, to gas), and then focusing in on wind and solar. A key theme is the role of economics in the transition to renewable energy and how the 'learning curve' and economies of scale bring down the cost over time to make it gain traction and eventually reach convergence with fossil fuels. The book also uses interesting case studies such as Tesla's effect on the cost of lithium-ion batteries. I learnt about lots of interesting things like the levelised cost of electricity, capacity factors, command and control policies, the duck curve, and the Keeling curve.

Title: How the World Really Works: A Scientist's Guide to Our Past, Present and Future
Author: Vaclav Smil
My Review: Books that try to cover a lot of material, cover grand narratives, and make things click together are difficult to pull off (though see Sapiens and Guns, Germs and Steel). Unfortunately, Vaclav Smil has not pulled it off with How the World Really Works. He is details-oriented to a fault: most of the book is pages and pages of very specific information and calculations that ironically don't add up to much.  I got the impression of a clearly knowledgeable and intelligent man just pouring his brain out onto the page with very little narrative, insight, or analysis.

Title: The Poisonwood Bible
Author: Barbara Kingsolver
My Review:
The book is summed up well with the following quotation: "You can't just sashay into the jungle aiming to change it all over to the Christian style, without expecting the jungle to change you right back."

This is an epic story of an ill-fated Christion missionary expedition in the Congo on the cusp of independence in 1960. It uses a diary format to follow the experiences of an American family in unfamiliar territory: four daughters, their mother, and their psychotic fire-and-brimstone preacher father. After a series of calamitous events, the family flees the Congo and the book follows the trajectories of the daughters over the next few decades. The writing here was excellent (though at times it wasn't totally clear what was going on), and the themes of religious faith (particularly its loss), cultural differences, and language were fascinating. This is also the only book I've ever read that features my favourite animal, the okapi!!

Title: Becoming
Author: Michelle Obama
My Review: This was OK, but definitely not unputdownable. It was semi-interesting from a social mobility perspective (Michelle Obama's impressive educational and career trajectory given her background), but mostly interesting for her perspective of life in the White House.

Title: Frog Music
Author: Emma Donoghue
My Review: Ergh, what a slog. Interesting setting, but confusing, jumbled, and too long. The skips between time points were very unclear and I lost the will to reread/check early on.

Title: Thatcher and Sons: A Revolution in Three Acts
Author: Simon Jenkins
My Review: This was an absolute slog. I just wanted to read about the recent political history of Britain, and couldn't find anything on Thatcher that wasn't overly long or biased. The biographical parts of this book were sometimes interesting, but it went on for too long about minute policy details that just meant nothing to me. The idea of the two-part political revolution carried through from Thatcher to Brown also wasn't very clearly explained in my view, perhaps because you 'had to be there' to understand the events and references. First revolution: privisatisation; second revolution: increased centralisation and regulation...? The main idea is that Thatcher's policies are seen as extreme but actually they were continued to a more vigorous degree by her successors, even in the Labour party.

Title: Dominion: The History of England from the Battle of Waterloo to Victoria's Diamond Jubilee (The History of England, #5)
Author: Peter Ackroyd
My Review: 3.5 stars. Such an interesting century, such a brief book - Ackroyd obviously has to be selective, but it would have been nicer to have slightly less political content. Neverthless, I learnt a lot from this, especially about Chartism and the various reform acts. By now I'm used to having to read these books with Wikipedia open (and especially a list of prime ministers), as seemingly important details are often glossed over or missed out.

Title: I Let You Go
Author: Clare Mackintosh
My Review: 2.5. I chose this because I wanted something modern and pacey, and saw it on several lists of 'unputdownable' books. Unfortunately the synopsis didn't make clear that it was a hackneyed detective story - a mysterious crime, a woman with a secret past, a world-weary detective and an almost-affair with his partner, a twist, a happy ending - otherwise I'd have given it a miss.

Title: The Buried Giant
Author: Kazuo Ishiguro
My Review:
Quite disappointed with this. The Buried Giant is a story of a couple (Beatrice and Axl) in Anglo-Saxon England on a journey to find their long-lost son. It's very much of the fantasy genre, with ogres, pixies, and a she-dragon who casts a memory-erasing 'mist' over the land. Beatrice and Axl get roped into a side-quest involving Wistan the Saxon warrior and Sir Gawain the gnarled Arthurian knight. What unfolds is an attempt to kill the she-dragon and thus end the 'mist'. (The book's synopsis does a very poor job of describing the story IMO)

The setting, characters, and events were rather 'Game of Thrones', but the writing style was stuffy and slow. I didn't really buy in to the relationship between Beatrice and Axl (and for god's sake man, stop calling her 'princess' in every utterance!). The whole book supposedly hinges on this relationship and their love for each other, so I just didn't get it. I also disliked the lack of demonstrative pronouns (who/that), e.g. "it's something always puzzled me too..." Just why?!

Title: The Life of an MP: Everything You Really Need to Know About Politics
Author: Jess Phillips
My Review: I like Jess Phillips. She's unusual for a politican because she's straight-talking and down to earth, and not from a privileged background. This book is about Phillips' life as an MP since 2015 but also delves frequently into her own life and background. I think the title "Everything you need to know..." is a bit misleading, even though the book does cover a range of topics across its 12 chapters. Phillips is shadow minister for domestic violence and safeguarding, and accordingly most of her examples and anecdotes revolve around issues emanating from this post. The writing style tries to be informal and irreverent, but the tone just grated on me. I think there's also (a possibly unintentional) 'holier-than-thou' theme throughout the book as Phillips contrasts herself with various (Conservative party) politicians and their shenanigans. For me, the highlight was the chapter on constituency work and the various kind of activities this entails.

Title: Notes on a Scandal
Author: Zoë Heller
My Review: This is a story about a schoolteacher's illicit affair with a student. It centers around the unlikely friendship between Barbara and Sheba, and is told retrospectively from Barbara's perspective (the style reminded me of Ishiguro's writing). Barbara's true role in the proceedings is gradually revealed throughout the book. She is less an unreliable narrator than simply a nasty piece of work!

Title: The Class Ceiling: Why it Pays to be Privileged
Author: Sam Friedman
My Review:
The Class Ceiling provides an up-to-date picture of social inequality in some of Britain's elite professions using data from the Labour Force Survey and interviews with people from four case study professions (architecture, accountancy, media, and acting). Its key take home message is that meritocracy is a myth, and access to and progress in elite professions is still largely determined by a peron's social background.

People from upper middle class backgrounds are 3.6 times more likely to be in one of the elite professions of law, journalism, medicine, and architecture. They are also likely to earn more than their working class colleagues who attended the same universities and attained first degrees. Most of the book deals with the drivers of social inequality in the workplace, revealed through extensive interviews. Some of the key hidden mechanisms include behavioural codes (having the 'right' accent, dress, and a sense of 'polish'), informal sponsorship, and ‘social closure' or gatekeeping. The key to understanding many of these mechanisms is the concept of ‘homophily', or individuals being tied through cultural affinity (i.e. those more likely to get sponsored/promoted tend to share cultural ties with those already in positions of power). No wonder that people from working class backgrounds often resort to acts of ‘self-elimination', suffering feelings of insecurity and estrangement from their upbringing that result in the avoidance of opportunities to progress.

This was a good read (albeit depressing) and I found it was pitched at the right level. Note that all of the above is nicely illustrated in another report by Sam Friedman in 2021 concerning social inequality in the UK civil service ('Navigating the labyrinth').

Title: Cloud Cuckoo Land
Author: Anthony Doerr
My Review: A book is "a repository, a resting place for the memories of people who have lived before"... "a story is a way of stretching time". These quotes sum up the essence of Cloud Cuckoo Land. In what feels like classic Anthony Doerr style, different characters in the past, present, and future are bound together in this book through an ancient Greek manuscript. Because it included many more characters and settings than his previous books, this one felt a little more fragmented but was still a great read.

Title: Napoleon the Great
Author: Andrew Roberts
My Review: At over 800 pages, this is a very comprehensive introduction to the Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars as well as to Napoleon himself. The USP of this book is that it's based on voluminous source material made avaiable by the Fondation Napoleon only ten years prior to its publication. The writing is clear and balanced and Roberts attempts to cover every aspect including the historical and political context, Napoleon's personality, and of course the battles (I only felt the need to skip pages when Roberts plodded through the military minutiae of battles, but I guess he had to please everyone). The history of this period is rather difficult and byzantine, with so many things going on (e.g. the various coalitions). But I feel I'm in a much better position to tackle now this having read the book.

Title: The No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency
Author: Alexander McCall Smith
My Review: 2.5 stars. It was a very simple and quick read and Botswana is certainly an interesting setting. But I found it a little too simple, perhaps too shallow.

Title: The Moon Is Down
Author: John Steinbeck
My Review: It's always a pleasure to read Steinbeck, no matter the subject. This is an interesting novella about an anonymous town (probably in Norway?) that is invaded by an anonymous enemy (obviously the Nazis). It deals with the perspectives of each side and ultimately the futility of war.

Title: The Fifth Child
Author: Doris Lessing
My Review: An idiotic couple are perturbed when their fifth child is born with some kind of developmental disorder. I suppose the underlying theme is that of maternal love even in the face of turmoil. This didn't have the usual level of depth of Lessing's other works since it was so short, and I just thought it was silly (eg the talk of the child being another species). And not a SINGLE paragraph break or chapter to be found in the whole book, argh!

Title: Summertime
Author: J.M. Coetzee
My Review: Strange book. In an alternate reality where Coetzee has died, a biographer visits people he used to know who all express their disappointment with him ("in all the time I was with him I never had the feeling I was with an exceptional person, a truly exceptional human being"). But of course this is all written by Coetzee himself, so is this just an exercise in broadcasting his low self-esteem (despite his several accolades including the Nobel Prize)?! I'd have thought a true autiobiography would be much more interesting.

Title: Klara and the Sun
Author: Kazuo Ishiguro
