My Review: I enjoyed this, and like Ishiguro's other works, it's a bit of a slow burn. Klara is an Artificial Friend brought in to provide accompaniment to Josie, an ailing teenage girl. I think perhaps one theme in the book was the idea that one day AI will become incredibly impressive and show amazingly human-like qualities (personality, hope, rumination, loyalty) but that other things will remain out of its reach (particularly love). For all the things Klara gets right and for all her astute observations, she nevertheless maintains a bizarre theistic relationship with the sun, and possesses the hugely mistaken belief that it can save Josie. The book also touches on other themes like family dynamics, social inequality, genome editing, and loss of jobs due to automation.

Title: My Traitor's Heart: Blood and Bad Dreams: A South African Explores the Madness in His Country, His Tribe and Himself
Author: Rian Malan
My Review:
My Traitor's Heart is a part-autobiography, part-apartheid-era-memoir by journalist and writer Rian Malan. Most of the book consists of vignettes of violence and racism perpetrated by the white Afrikaner establishment against the black population of South Africa, but also of violence within this population itself (e.g. between the ANC and UDF; between warring Zulu factions). What made the book particularly interesting was Malan's own dual personality: he has a 'traitor's heart' because he is split between being "a Just White Man and an Afrikaner with a disease of the soul". He describes himself as a left-leaning liberal who is vehemently against apartheid, yet is simultaneously subject to an ingrained historical racist ideology he must fight within himself. The book was a good read, though harrowing in many places. I think it would help to have some background knowledge of South African history to appreciate it.

I'm going to note here some of the memorable things I came across in this book:
- The brushing off of disgusting racist acts such as police brutality as "just another of those South African things"
- Malan's description of fear and ignorance of the black population. Apartheid ideology promulgated the idea of 'separate development' and the idea that blacks and whites are irrevocably different. Malan was therefore scared to ask questions about black culture, for fear of unwittingly 'playing into' this ideology. He contends that mutual fear leads to intractable ethnic violence.
- The story of Simon the Hammerman, a black man so belittled and crushed by white oppression that he took to murdering white families as they slept in their beds. His lawyers' exploration of the idea of 'political forensic psychology' - the idea that perhaps apartheid could be a mitigating factor in Simon's behaviour.
- The Randfontein miners' riots led by Themba Ngwazi.
- The image of a mourning white mother enraged at her son's heart being donated to a black man. The image of an elderly white woman losing her sight, enraged at accidentally waving to black people on the street (the petty nature of racism).
- Malan's hilarious description of the Afrikaans language: 'We're speaking the tongue of my tribe, a guttural bastard Dutch in which the r's roll like thunder and the g's grate like a shovel in cold gravel. It is a brutal language..."
- The story of Neil Alcock, the white farmer who was incensed by the dumping of surplus milk wile black Africans starved. His unjust death at the hands of warring Zulus. This is the final part of the novel and the story caused Malan to question his liberal worldview.

Title: Piranesi
Author: Susanna Clarke
My Review:
I'm afraid I just didn't get this one. It reminded me of Doggerland, which I hated. Two characters in a strange place with not much happening for large swathes of the book, and the protagonist's gradual dawning of the truth.

As far as I can tell, this is a story of a feud between two ex-academics/occultists which plays out in an alternate dimension (great halls with statues). Piranesi/Matthew is a journalist (?) who was investigating one of the occultists and somehow ends up trapped in this other world and loses his memory. Through journals he discovers his previous identity and is eventually saved.

I couldn't care less for the endless description of the halls themselves, but rather wanted to know more about why he was trapped there and what motivated the feud between the occultists. The book is surely highly metaphorical/allegorical because otherwise it's just silly. But I don't know what metaphors or allegories are supposed to be evoked here - perhaps the loss of childlike innocence as Piranesi discovers more about the real world and his past life? I didn't enjoy the book enough to spend any more time considering other possibilities.

Title: A Moveable Feast
Author: Ernest Hemingway
My Review: I enjoyed Hemingway's memoir way more than I enjoyed any of his books. In this short work he recounts his time in 1920s Paris among the 'lost generation', including Gertrude Stein, Ezra Pound, Sylvia Beach, and James Joyce. At that time, Hemingway was first starting out as a full-time writer and I liked his descriptions of working in various cafes and restaurants. The latter sections on F Scott Fitzgerald and his toxic relationship with Zelda were also entertaining.

Title: A Room of One's Own
Author: Virginia Woolf
My Review: In order to write fiction, a woman needs a room of her own and a sufficient annual income. Over the course of 6 short chapters, Virginia Woolf justifies this conclusion by considering some of the societal, institutional, and economic factors holding women back from creating Great Art. She applies these to the imagined case of Shakespeare's sister; a woman of equal talent who, simply due to her sex and society's expectations, is thwarted artistically and whose life ends tragically, all in stark contrast to her brother Bill. I appreciated the points made in A Room of One's Own (many of which are no doubt still as relevant today as in 1929), but I'm not a fan of Woolf's typical meandering, distracted and at times incomprehensible style.

Title: The Golden Notebook
Author: Doris Lessing
My Review: The Golden Notebook is like a roiling ocean with islands of lucidity and insight. The 'story' is is about Anna Wulf, a single mother and one-time successful writer living in London who has a past in the Communist Party. Key themes are the (changing) role of women in society and the idea of disintegration (political and mental). The book is chopped up and moves between a free-standing novel ('Free Women'), and a series of Anna's notebooks which deal with different topics like politics, Anna's time in Africa, her thoughts on being a writer etc (the final, Golden Notebook supposedly ties these all together, but I didn't get that impression). I think the book is a product of its time and needs to be interpreted within the context of 1950s/60s second-wave feminism and the post-WWII threat of nuclear war. It's a very messy novel, not only in terms of its structure, but in its content - numerous affairs, a drawn-out mental breakdown, a suicide attempt, a stepmother eloping with her stepson, and the bizarre relationship at the end between Anna and Saul. It was certainly a difficult read, with its stodgy prose and lack of chapters/line breaks!

Title: Agincourt: Henry V and the Battle that Made England
Author: Juliet Barker
My Review: This was great - it's about so much more than the battle itself, including the political context, medieval life, and most importantly a portrait of Henry V himself. Juliet Barker is a great storyteller, though at the same time she gives a balanced account according to the different sources available.

Title: Once There Were Wolves
Author: Charlotte McConaghy
My Review: The story of two Australian sisters, Inti and Aggie, who move to Scotland to work on a project rewilding wolves into the highlands. Of course they have a traumatic past etc which works its way into the story through flashbacks, and the protagonist Inti is interesting due to her condition (mirror-touch synaesthesia). But I found the rewilding aspect of the book most interesting - the deleterious effects of eliminating apex predators ('trophic cascades') and friction between conservationists and farmers. For me, Aggie's actions towards the end were a bit off, and I don't think the ending gelled very well. But overall, a pretty good read.

Title: The WEIRDest People in the World: How the West Became Psychologically Peculiar and Particularly Prosperous
Author: Joseph Henrich
My Review:
This was a difficult read at times, but I'm glad I persevered with it. Henrich uses a cultural psychology lens to pick up where Jared Diamond left off in Guns, Germs, and Steel (and in so doing offers better explanations for things like the Industrial Revolution and global variation in psychology today).

The book's main thesis is that societies used to be heavily kin-based (polygamy, cousin marriage) but this was curtailed by the Catholic church in the middle ages which banned such practices. Henrich explains: "when relational bonds are fewer and weaker, individuals need to forge mutually beneficial relationships, often with strangers. To accomplish this, they must distinguish themselves from the crowd by cultivating their own distinct set of attributes, achievements, and dispositions". As Europens became more individualistic and prosocial towards strangers, they established voluntary organisations, universal laws, the scientific method, etc. Protestantism really catalysed this underlying psychology, which helped to spark literacy and a particular work ethic.

The first part of the book was quite drawn out and full of jargon, but it gets more interesting after that as the reader starts to appreciate how each part of the puzzle fits together.

Title: Tournaments: Jousts, Chivalry and Pageants in the Middle Ages
Author: Richard Barber
My Review: One of the most boring books I've ever read. Way too long, way too detailed, way too repetitive. No narrative structure, just a succession of points: this person did this thing in this year in this place. Then this thing happened in this year in this place.

Title: Science Fictions: The Epidemic of Fraud, Bias, Negligence and Hype in Science
Author: Stuart Ritchie
My Review: A very well written and timely critique of modern scientific research. Ritchie examines the problematic nature of research, ranging from unintentional foibles to downright fraud, as well as the perverse incentives which encourage p-hacking, salami-slicing, and file-drawering. I like how the book considers these issues in light of the four Mertonian norms of science (universalism, communalism, disinterestedness, and organised scepticism).

Title: Oliver Twist
Author: Charles Dickens
My Review: Probably 3.5. Dickens' first 'proper novel' is the story of an orphan boy brought up in a workhouse. Only, it isn't really a story ABOUT Oliver, but rather the tug-of-war between the characters surrounding him. On the one hand, Oliver is exploited by Mr Bumble, Mrs Sowerberry, and Fagin, while on the other hand, he is protected by Mr Brownlow and Mrs Maylie who ultimately see the story through to its happy conclusion. I think nature/nurture is a key theme in this book, which is illustrated through the contrast of Nancy and Rose, both orphans but with very different life experiences.

Title: The Quarry
Author: Damon Galgut
My Review: Not a fan of this one. It reminded me of Blood Meridian but also The Stranger because it was oddly anhedonic and written in a stilted/staccato fashion (Then this happened. Then that happened). The first half of the book was fine, but then everything gets a bit weird after that and Galgut tries to be arty by doing away with punctuation and writing extremely short chapters. This quote sums up the book really: "It felt that his whole life had been expended in motion, had consisted of no substance but flight..." That's all the book is - characters who are constantly on the move, escaping, being hunted, just moving for the sake of it... no background, no reason for the reader to care about them.

Title: Fingersmith
Author: Sarah Waters
My Review: A complex Victorian-era story about double crossings, mental asylums, and love - what's not to love?! This was an excellent story, though at times I wished the story would have progressed a little faster.

Title: The Promise
Author: Damon Galgut
My Review: This was a good read. It follows the demise of a white South African family across four chapters and four funerals set roughly a decade apart. Aside from the social commentary and allegory, I found the characterisation excellent and enjoyed the somewhat unorthodox voice of the narrator.

Title: Milkman
Author: Anna Burns
My Review: Based on a young woman's perspective during the troubles in Northern Ireland, Milkman is written in a kind of stream-of-consciousness, tangent-hopping haze which makes for difficult reading. There were two points at which I nearly abandoned the book, but it does have pockets of lucidity. At times it was quite evocative; at other times I found myself thinking "what the hell are you going on about??" It was quite atmospheric, and made me think of the Reign of Terror during the French Revolution - "it was constant hints, symbolisms, representations, metaphors". The characters live in a fug of paranoia, gossip, and the constant threat of denunciation and violence.

Title: Superstition and Science
Author: Derek Wilson
My Review: So glad I finally finished this... it reads a bit like A Little History of Science (William Bynum) in that it contains little biographies of famous thinkers, but it's written more like a dissertation. I battled with it particularly in the first few chapters and although it got a little more interesting later on, it certainly wasn't a pleasure to read. I wanted more of the big-picture, i.e. what were the events that led to the flourishing of empirical investigation and science. Instead, I got overly-detailed chapters that were siloed from one another.

Title: The Tenant of Wildfell Hall
Author: Anne Brontë
My Review: I enjoyed this, my first Acton Bell novel. A story of toxic masculinity and a woman's suffociating position in Victorian society. Arthur Huntingdon is clearly a colossal prick, but Helen isn't totally blameless because she entered into the marriage fully cognisant of his reputation, thinking she could change him (though to be fair, her alternatives weren't much better).

Title: Revenge of the She-Punks: A Feminist Music History from Poly Styrene to Pussy Riot
Author: Vivien Goldman
My Review: I didn't enjoy this. It felt like an overwritten, thinly-veiled panegyric of the author's own life and all the famous people she knows. It was fun to follow up on some of the artists mentioned in the book, but I didn't get a strong sense of narrative and I don't feel like I learned much about the punk movement, though it got slightly better towards the end.

Title: A Fine Balance
Author: Rohinton Mistry
My Review: Set in India's 'Emergency' in 1975, this book weaves a thread between a number of characters whose lives intersect and end up forming a strong familial bond despite the odds. The book deals with many social themes, including male vs female roles, rural vs urban life, traditional vs modern values, and social status and the caste system. Overall, this was a good read and the writing was excellent. I liked how it delved into the backgrounds of the different characters, but some of the events that took place felt farfetched and at times it felt like the book was trying too hard to pull on readers' heartstrings. I also didn't really understand Maneck's character and his actions in the epilogue.

Title: Work:  A History of How we spend our Time
Author: James Suzman
My Review:
I didn't really enjoy this, perhaps because there was too much overlap with books like Sapiens and Guns, Germs and Steel. The author takes a long time to make his point, and I thought large parts of the book were unnecessary and didn't seem to relate to the question at hand (it felt like 'look how much I know about the various revolutions Homo Sapiens has been through' rather than being to the point). I bumped it up from 2 to 3 stars after looking at my Kindle highlights though because there were some interesting insights.

It's essentially a economics book trying to trash the 'economic problem' which says that we work because our desires are infinite but our means are limited (no, Suzman argues, there's evidence of humans doing work when it wasn't necessary). I think the book spent too much time on prehistory (and even discusses the second law of thermodynamics).

It's broadly chronological: cooking food gave us free time and represented the start of culture (transforming things). Even hunter-gatherers had free time, and this helped language to develop. Then early climate change created food scarcity, prompting people to start producing (farming) food. This led to surplus, writing, and specialisation of jobs but also bad things like pestilence and overpopulation. With the increasing efficiency of the Industrial Revolution (Taylorism), people felt more detached than ever from their work (Durkheim's 'anomie'). This efficiency also served to reduce working hours, but because of consumerism, people continued to work to afford the things they wanted to purchase. The rise of the third sector and 'bullshit jobs' in recent times shows how we continue to work hard because it gives us a sense of community and belonging.

The latter parts of the book were definitely the most interesting. Of course, a book on a huge topic like 'work' can never be exhaustive, but I'd have liked more content on the psychology of work and deeper probing into the notion that work gives us a sense of belonging and identity.

Title: The Book of Not
Author: Tsitsi Dangarembga
My Review: I didn't particularly enjoy this second instalment in the Nervous Conditions trilogy. From the very first chapter I found it confusing and jumbled, especially with respect to the war. The writing style is stuffier and more old-fashioned than in the first book (I also thought there was something quite Brontean about the writing and the story). Some things just didn't gel for me, for instance how Tambu studied so hard but achieved such poor grades, and the final part about her job as a copywriter, which felt tacked on. I won't be reading the third book.

Title: Southern African Wildlife: A Visitor's Guide
Author: Mike Unwin
My Review: Excellent guide, extremely well written and interesting.

Title: How Long Will South Africa Survive?: The Looming Crisis
Author: R.W. Johnson
My Review: OMG what a slog! I read this because it's cited in Gail Nattrass' A Short History of South Africa (2019). It was originally published in 1977 under the same title, so this is a major update. Johnson's major contention is that "South Africa can either choose to have an ANC government or a modern industrial economy", but not both. It's essentially a catalogue of fatal errors by the ANC party (corruption, mismanagement, etc) since Mandela up until 2015. It also gives insight into Zuma's presidency, exploring how his Zulu heritage effectively created a system of 'chiefly patronage' rather than a typical Western-style democracy. Of course, since the book's publication Zuma has been ousted (with over 300 deaths in the eventual fallout), running contemporaneously with Covid. No regime change just yet, but I think this will just strengthen Johnson's case that 'things have to go to get worse before they get better'. I haven't lived in SA since 2001 so of course this was going to be challenging, but Johnson makes it even harder with his writing, liberally peppering his dry lists of facts with names and references. Not a fun read, but I did learn some things (from the bits I didn't skip, anyway).

Title: Utopia For Realists
Author: Bregman  Rutger
My Review: I think I'm being generous in giving this 3 stars (only for its easy-to-read style and pockets of interestingness). Bregman champions three 'utopian' policies: universal basic income, a 15-hour workweek, and migration. These are massive topics and are only really skimmed over (UBI got the most attention, migration hardly any). The book just felt disorganised and rambly to me and I think it lacked a schema or lens to bring these things together.

Title: About Grace
Author: Anthony Doerr
My Review: I enjoyed this slightly less than All the Light We Cannot See, but it was still masterfully written - very evocative and vivid. You could say this novel is about time, memory, and finding joy in the small details. Or you could say it's about a weird hydrologist who abandons his family after dreaming of his baby daughter's death in a flood. Rather than stay and see his nightmare fulfilled, he flees the country and ends up in the West Indies where he ruminates for 25 years. Eventually he makes his way back to the states where he seeks out his adult daughter. The story and its protagonist were odd to say the least, but Doerr has a great way of tying things together and creating vivid imagery.

Title: Nervous Conditions
Author: Tsitsi Dangarembga
My Review: I really enjoyed this. Set in 1960s Zimbabwe, Tambu gets a life-changing opportunity to receive an education paid for by her uncle Babamukuru, arch-patriarch of the family. The story is told retrospectively and reads as a bildungsroman, but its themes include social mobility, culture clashes, and gender roles.

Title: Longitude: The True Story of a Lone Genius Who Solved the Greatest Scientific Problem of His Time
Author: Dava Sobel

Title: Daily Rituals: How Artists Work
Author: Mason Currey
My Review: I was going to accuse this book of being too thinly spread and not offering enough depth of insight. But then it's my own fault for not reading the book's synopsis properly: it covers the daily rituals of over 160 people in only 236 pages. These are vignettes into the working habits of famous writers, artists, and intellectuals, sometimes only half a page long. I think what would be more interesting would be a book that tries to synthesise commonalities in these routines and gives more in-depth case studies of interesting or outlying individuals.

Title: Long Walk to Freedom
Author: Nelson Mandela
My Review: What a life, what a story, what a struggle...

Title: The Good Terrorist
Author: Doris Lessing
My Review: I'd say that The Good Terrorist is a novel about identity conflict and the banality of revolution. It follows a group of squatters in 1980s London and focuses primarily on Alice Mellings, who comes from a privileged social background. Although she decries capitalism, Alice is also house proud and survives by stealing. She finds herself in the role of a responsible adult or housewife, cooking and cleaning for the others while they pursue their revolutionary activities. The 'comrades' of the squat are torn between allegiance to the IRA and Russia. I didn't really know where the novel was going, and it felt a little stodgy at times with the level of detail and minutiae of house-squat bureaucracy. However, the characterisation was excellent and by the end I almost felt like a member of the squat myself.

Title: Post Office
Author: Charles Bukowski
My Review: What was the point of this???

Title: Everybody Lies: What the Internet Can Tell Us About Who We Really Are
Author: Seth Stephens-Davidowitz
My Review: I don't particularly rate this book. It read like an overly long blogpost, with jaunty, clickbaity language to match. In fact, I think some of the studies in this book would have been better written up as blog articles, making use of multimedia to tell the story. Stephens-Davidowitz does spend a little bit of time discussing some of the issues with Big Data (e.g. the curse of dimensionality), but this cursory and comes too late in the book after he's tried to wow the reader with his attempt at Freakonomics.

Title: The Grass is Singing
Author: Doris Lessing
My Review: I wouldn't know where to start with a review for this one. I thought it was masterful and with excellent characterisation. Obviously it's a critique of apartheid and white colonialism, and for me it was a book about hatred and revenge. Mary hates society for pressuring her to marry and abandon her independent lifestyle; she's spitefully indifferent to her unambitious and flighty farmer husband Dick; she loathes her uneventful life on the farm, and she has disdain and even disgust for the 'natives'. I think she suffers cognitive dissonance when she comes to realise that the native houseboy, Moses, actually shows compassion (in caring for Dick when he falls ill) and even showing concern for Mary's own wellbeing. But he can't forget how she treated him in the past, and takes an opportunity to seek revenge. Not necessarily an easy read, but very well crafted and a lot to think about.

Title: Semicolon: How a misunderstood punctuation mark can improve your writing, enrich your reading and even change your life
Author: Cecelia Watson
My Review:
This book is a bit of a hodgepodge; it feels like an essay that's been plumped up to justify a book, but I still enjoyed it (the writing is excellent too). The title sounds ridiculously niche, but the book really just uses the semicolon to discuss issues around linguistic prescriptivism. Chapter 7 is where Watson hits her stride, giving examples of semicolon use from different authors. I learnt that, among other things, semicolons can be used to amplify parallel structure ('like a stone skipping across water'), and to signify pauses for reflection or uncertainty. If writers like Irvine Welsh can use semicolons effectively, they can't be *that* pretentious.

Watson also makes the point that grammar rules are just a stick to beat people with; that criticising someone's grammar or punctuation is really an ad hominem attack, detracting attention from substance and argument. I like her suggestion in the conclusion that instead of loving linguistic rules, what grammar nazis really value is tradition and orderliness, which I can relate to somewhat.

Title: Mystic River
Author: Dennis Lehane
My Review: After seeing so many glowing reviews for this book I find myself questioning whether I actually read the same thing... This was a typical detective drama with all the usual tropes and clichés. What grated on me was the casual, chatty tone of the writing throughout the book, and the huge number of American references that just passed me by.

Title: Flow: The Classic Work On How To Achieve Happiness: The Psychology of Happiness
Author: Mihály Csíkszentmihályi
My Review:
This isn't usually the kind of thing I read, but flow is a very zeitgeisty term so I thought I'd give it a go. Csikszentmihalyi states at the outset that he hasn't included references to studies in the main text in order to keep things simpler, but I would have preferred this to his philosophical, digressive writing style.

Flow is essentially when you're so absorbed in something that you lose track of time. It also has other qualifiers like it has to be intrinsically motivated and challenging to some extent. But the scope of 'flow' seems to be too wide-ranging to me (from surgery to drinking a glass of water) and for some reason he singles out TV as a non-example. I guess the main idea is the pursuit of your own goals leads to happiness, however defined.

Some of the ideas were interesting, though from reading around the subject it sounds like they're not really novel. What IS novel is the experience sampling method he developed, but that is hardly discussed; instead, the focus is on anecdata.

Title: Blood & Sugar
Author: Laura Shepherd-Robinson
My Review: This is a work of historical fiction set in late 18th century London. It's based on the Zong massacre of 1781 in which 130 slaves were murdered aboard a British slave ship (or rather 'destroyed', as they were considered property rather than people - a key theme of this book); here, the ship is called The Dark Angel' instead. When his abolitionist friend Tad is murdered in Deptford, war hero Harry Corsham becomes embroiled in a complex web of treachery in order to discover the identity of Tad's killer and pick up his investigation into the Dark Angel. I found the book interesting for its historical setting, and the writing is very good. However, that 'complex web' was a little too complex for me at times and given the book's length, I often struggled to remember who was who. It's really the kind of book that needs to be read in two or three sittings. But even then, I didn't find the ending very satisfying and I still didn't understand what motivated characters to do certain things.

Title: Elephants on Acid: And Other Bizarre Experiments
Author: Alex Boese
My Review: This was a fun read, and must have been great to research. Includes some classic A-level Psychology studies like Milgram and Zimbardo, among a panoply of bizarre and lesser-known research.

Title: The Ashes of London (James Marwood & Cat Lovett #1)
Author: Andrew  Taylor
My Review: Urgh. I read this because I picked up the 3rd instalment in Waterstones and thought I'd start at the beginning of the trilogy. I certainly won't be reading books 2 and 3... Sometimes books are long but they pay off in the end. Not so here. The climax (if it can be called that) comes after 400+ pages and was so thoroughly underwhelming that I thought I'd missed something. I didn't care for the writing or the characterisation. The only thing going for this book in my opinion is its setting, but even that aspect fizzled out fairly early on.

Title: Adventures in the Anthropocene: A Journey to the Heart of the Planet we Made
Author: Gaia Vince
My Review: This is probably a 4- or 5-star book (it did win the Royal Society Winton prize), but my rating reflects how much I enjoyed it. As other reviews point out, Adventures in the Anthropocene is essentially a travelogue cobbled out of Gaia Vince's globetrotting experiences. Across ten chapters (e.g. 'Atmosphere', 'Farmlands', 'Oceans, 'Forests', 'Rocks'), it discusses case studies from around the world (but typically in developing countries) of the consequences of human interference with the planet. At times it was a bit of a slog, but there were pockets of interesting things and I learnt about some cool technologies.

Title: Gunnar's Daughter
Author: Sigrid Undset
My Review: I really enjoyed this. Written in the style of a medieval Icelandic saga, it explores themes that were as relevant then as they are today.

Title: Perfect
Author: Rachel Joyce
My Review: My review has spoilers, but they really don't spoil much. This is a story about a child whose parents both commit suicide, and subsequently develops OCD. It's written at two time points (was it supposed to be shocking that Jim was actually Byron all along? I had guessed that pretty early on). Despite its themes of guilt, anxiety, and suicide, I didn't really feel for any of the characters, and the whole friendship between Diana and Beverley just left me bemused - it just seemed like a distraction.

Title: Empire Falls
Author: Richard Russo
My Review: I was enjoying this until about two thirds of the way through after which point I started to get bored. It's about a small, declining town in Maine and its various characters. The characterisation and writing are both very good, but the writing did feel somewhat dense. The school shooting incident and Miles' little rampage near the end were quite out of the blue, and overall I didn't finish the book entirely satisfied. Also, entire chapters in italic font are not a good idea!!

Title: The Go-between
Author: L.P. Hartley
My Review: I quite enjoyed this. Leo Colston reflects back on a summer spent at his upper class schoolmate's estate half a century earlier in 1900. The book is full of symbolism and is a sort of bildungsroman, dealing social class divisions and Leo's (mis)understanding of adult relationships and intentions. Blinded by his boyhood crush on his friend's older sister Marian and respect/fear for the working class farmer Ted Burgess, Leo is roped into becoming a go-between, carrying messages between the two as they carry out their affair.

Title: All That Remains: A Life in Death
Author: Sue Black
My Review: A memoir of Sue Black's career as a forensic anatomist / anthropologist and academic. I found it well written, and Black writes with great compassion and sensitivity, but it didn't really hold my interest (despite the macabre subject). I much preferred Unnatural Causes by Richard Shepherd.

Title: The Book Thief
Author: Markus Zusak
My Review: I think this was a 'I-don't-get-the-hype' kind of book for me. Yes, the story is a bit different because it's narrated by Death instead of a person, but the little side notes and enumerated lists that punctuate the chapters just annoyed me. The language was also strange. It felt like it had been badly translated, but the author is actually an anglophone! There were some interesting parts, but towards the end I was quite impatient to get it finished. It some respects it invites comparison with Anthony Doerr's All the Light We Cannot See, which is a MUCH better book. Maybe I was subconsciously comparing it to that.

Title: The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark
Author: Carl Sagan
My Review: Hmph, a bit disappointed with this given its raving reviews. Sagan writes well, but in this book he sometimes writes too much and seems to ramble a bit. Chapter 12 'The fine art of baloney detection' was the highlight for me.

Title: Transcendent Kingdom
Author: Yaa Gyasi
My Review: This was a good read, but quite a sad one. It reminded me a lot of Americanah by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie and Everything I Never Told You by Celeste Ng, also very good reads. Transcendent Kingdom has lots of themes running throughout it, including race, immigration, religion, mental health, higher education, and I even learnt something about optogenetics...

Title: A Town Like Alice
Author: Nevil Shute
My Review: I read this because I enjoyed On the Beach. A Town Like Alice has the same methodological, plodding storytelling style. It sets out the interesting continent-spanning life of Jean Paget who uses her inheritance to grow a little dustbowl town in the Australian outback. At times, the story was stymied by too much unnecessary detail, and for me, the choice of a floating narrator was awkward - the story in Australia would be in full swing and suddenly the narrator, based in London, would pop up unexpectedly. Published in 1950, the book is also very much a product of its time, reflected in what from a modern day perspective seems like rather cringeworthy language.

Title: The Doll Factory
Author: Elizabeth Macneal
My Review: Probably 3.5/5. A story set in mid-19th century London around the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood artistic movement. Good writing and character development, but quite predictable. Quite similar to The Crimson Petal and the White but much more interesting and less dense.

Title: The Chrysalids
Author: John Wyndham
My Review: A thought provoking story of a dystopian world in which genetic mutations run rife and attempt to be stamped out by an isolated fundamentalist religious agricultural society. The protagonist and a small group of his peers have a hidden "deviation" in the form of telepathy, though eventually get found out and flee. Sounds silly, but it was actually a good read (apart from the clipped writing style which made it difficult to understand what was happening in some places).

Title: How We Learn: The New Science of Education and the Brain
Author: Stanislas Dehaene
My Review:
I have mixed feelings about this book. On one hand, it's a very engaging synthesis of the cognitive science of learning, in a general sense. Dehaene dispels the myth of tabula rasa by showing that babies come into the world with pre-wired expectations and learning algorithms (and this is why machine learning has a lot to live up to, and there is a lot of comparison with artificial intelligence). A good example of this is Chomsky's idea of the language acquisition device and how infants engage in shared attention. Dehaene also deals with the nurture side of the debate, discussing brain plasticity, sensitive periods, and his neuronal recycling hypothesis in reading development. All fascinating stuff.

On the other hand, I feel that the book's subtitle ('the new science of education') is misleading; much of the work discussed here isn't strictly 'new', and much of it isn't directly relevant to education. For instance, the final section discussing the 'four pillars of learning', much of the work relates to animal studies or infants, with only a few light pepperings of education research. To some extent this reflects the dearth of scientific education research, something Dehaene acknowledges in the conclusion, but I wonder how some teachers would react to his 13 key take away messages such as 'enrich the environment', 'accept and correct mistakes', and 'set clear learning objectives'. Not exactly revolutionary. (I note how this subtitle has been changed from 'why brains learn better than any machine, for now' in the hardback edition - much more appropriate).

In conclusion, I think this book is best enjoyed with its original subtitle. Don't expect in-depth application of cognitive science to education, and just enjoy the neuroscience!

Title: Straight Man
Author: Richard Russo
My Review: I liked this, overall. The writing was good and the characters were interesting (though I sometimes got lost as to who was who in the hierarchy of academic staff). I liked it less as it went on, and I think it could have been shorter.

Title: A Little History of Literature
Author: John Sutherland
My Review: This was pretty good. It covers a huge amount of ground so does what it says on the tin. There was lots in here that I already knew, but lots that I didn't as well.

Title: How to Change Your Mind: The New Science of Psychedelics
Author: Michael Pollan
My Review: An interesting look at psychedelics. I found the history chapter a little convoluted and confusing with all the different names, but Pollan's own experiences on psychedelics, and the neuroscience chapter were great.

Title: Silence
Author: Shusako Endo
My Review: Bit of a different kind of read, this one. A Portuguese Catholic missionary in 17th century Japan whose faith is challenged when his god is 'silent' and does nothing to alleviate the suffering of the ostracised Christian minority. Quite Kafkaesque in places. I'm sure the ins and outs of the theological themes are lost on me, but it was still a good read.

Title: The Sum of the People: How the Census Has Shaped Nations, from the Ancient World to the Modern Age
Author: Andrew Whitby
My Review: Well written, and really interesting in parts. Sometimes took a while to make the point, and dragged the reader through a whole lot of other history to do so.

Title: Everything I Never Told You
Author: Celeste Ng
My Review: A sad story about the struggle for identity.

Title: On The Beach
Author: Nevil Shute
My Review: A 1950s take on the psychology of impending death from nuclear fallout. The characters remain amazingly steadfast and disciplined right until their demise, while living in a kind of mass folie à deux that life will continue as normal. No idea why it's called On the Beach - that was pretty misleading!

Title: Men Without Women: Stories
Author: Haruki Murakami
My Review: What a pity to end my reading year with this. I'm imposing a Murakami moratorium from this point on because I've tried and tried, but I just don't get it. This is a collection of short stories - about infidelity for the most part - which at first come across as deep and profound but end up leaving you dazed and confused and unsure of what the whole point was.

Title: The Crimson Petal and the White
Author: Michel Faber
My Review: I vacillated between 2 and 3 stars for this one. A good story, but way too long and dense. It also had an abrupt and unsatisfying ending.

Title: Language at the Speed of Sight: How We Read, Why So Many Can't, and What Can Be Done About It
Author: Mark Seidenberg
My Review: I guess it's tricky reading about a topic you're already somewhat knowledgeable about. That aside, the book tries to cover a bit too much ground, and it was a bit of a slog in places. I often had the impression that Seidenberg was using too many words to say too little, and I actually found his attempts to be funny annoying. The notes at the back are pretty useful though.

Title: The Brontes
Author: Juliet Barker
My Review: Wow wow wow! Other than having read Wuthering Heights and Jane Eyre, I knew nothing about the history of the Brontes before reading this. Juliet Barker's writing is masterful yet measured, and I love how she examines the evidence for particular claims and beliefs.

Title: Anxious People
Author: Fredrik Backman
My Review: For me, the book's desperate attempts to be funny and poignant just fell flat. The setup sounded interesting, delving into the back stories of a group of strangers who find themselves in a 'hostage situation'. But I just found it too silly.

Title: Range: How Generalists Triumph in a Specialized World
Author: David   Epstein
My Review: I'm glad I read this. I've always gone through phases of interests and have never been able to settle on just one area I'd like to specialise in. The central idea of this book is that sampling widely is a good thing, and can have a competitive advantage over hyperspecialisation. The book is well written but for me it fell down due to its overly-detailed tangents and reliance on anecdotes.

Title: Deep Work: Rules for Focused Success in a Distracted World
Author: Cal Newport
My Review: Self-help books are not representative of my typical reading diet, and I'm glad. This book is an academic's perspective about how somewhat nebulously defined "knowledge workers" can better engage in equally vague "deep work". Of course Newport needs to establish his credentials before doling out advice, but he doesn't need to bang on about how amazing he is all the time. I hated the tone of this book, but that's probably symptomatic of the self-help genre in general. Among the rules and tips given for doing deep work are "quit social media", "become hard to reach" and to set up an email responder telling people how important you are and how sacrosanct your time is and basically not to expect a reply. I would hate to have colleagues like that! I don't understand the hype about this book.

Title: Doughnut Economics: Seven Ways to Think Like a 21st-Century Economist
Author: Kate Raworth
My Review: Ugh, so glad I finally finished this. It started out really well but by chapter 4 I was starting to skip sections. There are some interesting ideas in it though. I think this is the last economics book I'll read - I know how important economics is but I've tried and failed multiple times to understand it and be interested by it.

Title: My Year of Rest and Relaxation
Author: Ottessa Moshfegh
My Review: A story about a psychotropic drug-fuelled hibernation from depression doesn't necessarily sound appealing, but I enjoyed this. It's dark, misanthropic, narcissistic, insalubrious, irreverent, and funny in some places.

Title: The Pillars of the Earth (Kingsbridge, #1)
Author: Ken Follett
My Review: A 40-year medieval saga set in the time of King Stephen, Henry II, and Thomas Becket. I have mixed feelings about Pillars of the Earth - the story is fast-paced and contains a rich web of characters, but reads like a YA novel and is very predictable (also, I think Ken Follett is obsessed with breasts...)

Title: The Noonday Demon: An Atlas of Depression
Author: Andrew Solomon
My Review: This book is a masterfully written tour de force of depression, furnished throughout with personal testimonies of many different people. It was a good read, despite being dated and US-centric (I skipped most of the Politics chapter and didn't have enough energy left for the long epilogue!). I particularly enjoyed the chapters on the history and evolution of depression.

Title: The Bang Bang Club
Author: Greg Marinovich
My Review: A harrowing memoire of the Bang Bang Club, a group of conflict photographers covering South Africa's transition to democracy in the early 1990s.

Title: Eileen
Author: Ottessa Moshfegh
My Review: I enjoyed this! Very dark and very tense.

Title: The End of Average: How to Succeed in a World that Values Sameness
Author: Todd Rose
My Review: This book is interesting and very readable, but I find its arguments unconvincing. The main thrust is that the concept of the average does a poor job of describing variability and individuality, and that this has to stop. I find this disappointing because as an academic - in developmental psychology of all disciplines! - Rose must know that researchers are aware that the within/between distinction is not new, and statistics has good ways of dealing with variability (the normal distribution, mixed effects modelling, and so on). More time could have been spent on how the concept of an average is actually useful (e.g. in medical screening), and of course we only base hiring decisions and educational selection on the average because it's the most efficient way of dealing with an overwhelming number of applicants/students. The book is quite idealistic, and its examples are mostly restricted to the North American context.

Title: Age of Iron
Author: J.M. Coetzee
My Review: I didn't enjoy this very much. The synopsis sounded so interesting but it's quite misleading. Yes, this story is set in the later stages of apartheid but really it's about an old woman who befriends a squatter on her property and loses her mind as she dies from cancer. The writing got increasingly stream-of-consciousness in style, which I personally didn't care for as it just wasn't clear at times what was going on or why.

Title: Into Thin Air: A Personal Account of the Mt. Everest Disaster
Author: Jon Krakauer
My Review: Hmm, 3 stars for the content but 4 for the writing, so 3.5 overall. There's a lot to be said about this book because of its backstory. At its heart it's a retelling of 'the Everest disaster' that Krakauer experienced, which was originally published as a magazine article. However, there were rival perspectives and retellings and so there's a big focus on factual integrity which unfortunately took away from the storytelling for me. In addition to this focus, or perhaps because of it, I found it quite confusing to figure out what was actually happening at the point of the storm hitting, and the multiple climbing parties and characters involved also made it confusing at times. That said, the writing is excellent and I'd still recommend it.

Title: The Dark Side of the Mind: True Stories from My Life as a Forensic Psychologist
Author: Kerry Daynes
My Review: This part-professional, part-personal memoir Daynes' career as a forensic psychologist is very similar to Unnatural Causes by Richard Shepherd (although much less harrowing and obviously focused on psychology rather than pathology). It's very well written and the stories of Daynes' past patients and experiences are engaging.

Title: All the Light We Cannot See
Author: Anthony Doerr

Title: Me, Myself, and Us: The Science of Personality and the Art of Well-Being
Author: Brian Little
My Review: I heard about Brian Little in Susan Cain's 'Quiet Revolution' and thought I'd like to know more about his ideas on free trait theory. Unfortunately, Cain's is a MUCH better book despite being more narrowly focused. For me, Little's writing is overly chatty and way too many pages were spent on anecdotes. Towards the end I had to start skipping parts because it just wasn't holding my attention.

Title: Zero Degrees of Empathy: A New Theory of Human Cruelty
Author: Simon Baron-Cohen
My Review: I found this a totally engrossing read. Baron-Cohen sets out his ideas on how the psychological mechanisms of empathising and systemising can lead to lack of empathy, splitting this into zero-negative (personality disorders) and zero-positive (autism spectrum disorders). He also delves into causal factors like attachment and throws in some neuroscience too. I found the writing lucid, and I think the book delivers its messages without being overly verbose.

Title: An Artist of the Floating World
Author: Kazuo Ishiguro
My Review: After enjoying Never Let Me Go and The Remains of the Day I was disappointed with this one. It always felt like it was leading up to something, but that something never transpired. Maybe you need to know quite a lot about Japan's pre/post-war transition to understand this?

Title: Revolution (The History of England, #4)
Author: Peter Ackroyd
My Review: I like the books in this series less and less over time. I know it's only a brief overview of 'the long 18th century', but it seemed to cut corners/leapfrog over certain things. I'd have liked more commentary on the broad themes and ideas that developed over the century (i.e. people talk about this century as being characterised by revolution, but this didn't really come across to me in the book). Also, as I make notes as I go along, I get frustrated when Ackroyd makes reference to, e.g. a 'war' that started in '1795', prompting a distracting Googling session!

Title: Americanah
Author: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
My Review: A brilliant read. A transcontinental novel dealing with big themes like race, immigration, and identity, all told through an absorbing, sharply written narrative.

Title: America, Empire of Liberty: A New History
Author: David   Reynolds
My Review: This is a tour de force! A very good balance between breadth and depth. Reynolds quotes regularly from direct sources, giving greater insight into the events and people discussed. Excellent quote from the final page: the history of the United States is "shot through with paradox - the empire forged by anti-imperialists, the land of liberty that rested on slavery, the secular state energized by godly ambition."

Title: North and South
Author: Elizabeth Gaskell
My Review: What a slog this was. There were some interesting events and themes, but not enough to justify the length of the book.

Title: How Music Works
Author: David Byrne
My Review: This one was hit-and-miss for me. David Byrne is clearly a sensitive and intellectual producer and consumer of music, and his candid insights into the music industry were interesting. But too often this slipped into autobiographical drudgery (more like 'How MY Music Works'), and often chapters felt disorganised and lacking in direction.

Title: The River
Author: Tricia Wastvedt
My Review: A difficult read due to the complex web of characters and time-shifting, exacerbated by a writing style which I didn't care for.

Title: The Remains of the Day
Author: Kazuo Ishiguro
My Review: A novel about pathological devotion and loyalty

Title: Suspicious Minds: Why We Believe Conspiracy Theories
Author: Rob Brotherton
My Review: This seems like a good general introduction to the field with lots of references to follow up on. A very easy read, but too much time is spent discussing the minutiae of actual conspiracy theories at the expense of analysing why people believe them. Other parts of the book also felt unnecessarily padded out.

Title: Uncommon Knowledge: the Economist Explains
Author: Tom Standage
My Review: An interesting compendium of bitesize articles on a range of interesting subjects.

Title: Half of a Yellow Sun
Author: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
My Review: A brilliant, complex novel set around the Nigerian civil war.

Title: The Martian
Author: Andy Weir
My Review: It's painfully obvious that this is written by a science-loving ex-computer programmer. I glazed over on several occasions when Weir went into way too much detail, using way too much jargon. I feel this would have been a much better story if there had been more emphasis on character development and what it would actually feel like to be stranded on Mars. I found Watney's character annoying chipper and unfunny.

Title: NW
Author: Zadie Smith
My Review: I quite enjoyed this - a vivid character study touching on themes of social class and mobility in London amongst many other things.

Title: Civil War (The History of England, #3)
Author: Peter Ackroyd
My Review: Another great instalment in the History of England series. Would have liked more analysis/summarising throughout, and also more focus on the social and scientific changes of the period.

Title: Behave: The Biology of Humans at Our Best and Worst
Author: Robert M. Sapolsky
My Review: "We've covered lots of ground," Sapolsky says in the epilogue at the end of this marathon. No shit. For me, this the reason why this book fails. It covers so much from so many different scientific disciplines that I found myself either switching off, or feeling overwhelmed (that said, it did get more interesting as it went on and got further away from the 'hard' science). Having read books by Steven Pinker, Jonathan Haidt, Richard Dawkins, Jarod Diamond et al., I came across a lot of debates and ideas I already knew about, and although I respect Sapolsky as a scientist, I wasn't a fan of his writing style (I got so sick of 'scads of...' and 'stay tuned'!). I'm sure I've learnt lots of things from this book, but right after having finished it I couldn't really verbalise these to anyone.

Title: Understanding Psychology as a Science: An Introduction to Scientific and Statistical Inference
Author: Zoltan Dienes
My Review:
This is a very good 'further reading' or extension book for anyone with knowledge of basic statistics, and it's definitely relevant outside of Psychology. The book gets increasingly technical as it goes on, beginning with two chapters on the philosophy of science covering Popper, Kuhn, and Lakatos. These chapters are lucid and easy to understand. The book then goes on to set out three particular paradigms in statistical inference: the Neyman-Pearson method (which is what you were probably taught if you studied Psychology undergrad); Bayesian statistics, and finally likelihood inference. I learnt lots here despite my prior stats training.

I don't usually add textbooks to my read list but I did actually read all of this! I came across this book in Bodo Winter's 'Statistics for Linguistics' R textbook as recommended reading.

Title: The Silent Patient
Author: Alex Michaelides
My Review: Easy to read, keeps your interest, big twist at the end. But I didn't rate the writing style and thought the characters were very 2D.

Title: Babel: Around the World in Twenty Languages
Author: Gaston Dorren
My Review: This book covers the 20 most widely-spoken languages in the world. The chapters are very inconsistent, flitting from overly-conversational to overly-technical; some focus on the sociology and history of a language, others on linguistic features.

Title: Blueprint: How DNA Makes Us Who We Are (The MIT Press)
Author: Robert Plomin
My Review: I didn't really enjoy this. Quite short, but also quite repetitive. It's all in the strapline: how DNA makes us who we are -the environment doesn't get a look in, and nothing on epigenetics. The second part discussed the forthcoming DNA revolution, but it's a lot of words to describe something that hasn't happened yet...

Title: Musicophilia: Tales of Music and the Brain
Author: Oliver Sacks
My Review: A fascinating collection of case studies showing how the brain really does have a special place for music. This seems to be a mixture of patients which Sacks had already described in other places (e.g. An Anthropologist on Mars), and I can't help feeling that Musicophilia plays second fiddle to these. (Note that only 66% of this Kindle edition is actually the book - the rest is footnotes and bibliography).

Title: Under the Banner of Heaven: A Story of Violent Faith
Author: Jon Krakauer
My Review: I really enjoyed this: a thorough and entertaining history of Mormonism and its fundamentalist schism. It juxtaposes two stories - the history of Joseph Smith and the Mormon exodus, and the brutal murder committed by the fundamentalist Lafferty brothers in 1984. What I found fascinating were the questions around the thin line between mental illness and religious fanaticism (brought out in the discussion of the Laffertys' court case), and the role of burgeoning documentary evidence in exposing the skulduggery perpetrated by followers of the religion.

Title: Blood Meridian
Author: Cormac McCarthy
My Review: It was a huge relief to have finished this. I sense that it's a good story, but in my opinion McCarthy makes it very hard for the reader. The whole thing felt like a dream in which you have a general sense of anxiety but aren't really sure why.

Title: Educated
Author: Tara Westover
My Review: A great memoir; the ultimate example of imposter syndrome!

Title: The Body: A Guide for Occupants
Author: Bill Bryson
My Review: Another wonderfully written non-fiction work from Bill Bryson. This book is incredibly wide-ranging (literally from birth to death), and I particularly enjoyed the stories around the various discoveries and inventions. For every fact that I had already come across, there were another 4 or 5 that I hadn't.

Title: Lady Audley's Secret
Author: Mary Elizabeth Braddon
My Review: I really enjoyed this - a Victorian blockbuster! Can be read for the simple pleasure of the mystery-solving narrative or more deeply as a social commentary.

Title: No Logo: Taking Aim at the Brand Bullies
Author: Naomi Klein
My Review: I'd heard No Logo being talked about in a few different places (i.e. as one of Radiohead's inspirations) so thought I'd give it a go. Obviously a lot has changed in the 20 years since it was published, although I'm sure modern brands are still engaging in military-grade skulduggery, just in different channels. This book was a bit of a slog for me - the writing is high quality, but there's a lot of it...

Title: A Concise History of the Modern World, Fourth Edition: 1500 to the Present:  A Guide to World Affairs
Author: William Woodruff
My Review: An authoritative crash course in modern world history. This is not a gentle, hand-holding, traipse through world events; readers would benefit greatly from at least some background knowledge. That said, you're always free to look things up along the way.

Title: Doggerland
Author: Ben   Smith
My Review: What a slog this was. It seemed pretty pointless as a story, if you could even call it that. All the way through it felt very difficult to visualise what was going on, and I didn't appreciate pages and pages being spent on really nothing happening at all.

Title: The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter
Author: Carson McCullers
My Review: This was a slow burner. Not much happens, but it's an interesting character study.

Title: When the Lion Feeds
Author: Wilbur Smith
My Review: This story could accurately be described as 'epic' - a sort of bildungsroman that takes place in late 19th century South Africa. It crams a lot of events into its pages including the Anglo-Zulu war and the gold rush. I think if you politely excuse the fact that this was written in 1964, and don't dwell too much on the - at times stilted - writing style, then there is a great story to be enjoyed here. It does end rather abruptly and depressingly, but then I suppose that's forgivable in a series of 18 books!

Title: A Short History of South Africa
Author: Gail Nattrass
My Review: This is definitely a good overview text which clearly makes an effort to include the stories and perspectives of those traditionally neglected by history books. However I don't think the writing style is the best, and it could have done with some photographs of the events/people covered.

Title: Murder on the Orient Express (Hercule Poirot, #10)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review: Definitely a product of its time (1930s), but a classic murder-mystery story that genuinely kept my interest.

Title: Why We Get the Wrong Politicians
Author: Isabel Hardman
My Review: Hmm, slightly misleading title. Should be more like "What it's Like to Be a Politician in Britain". This book is very much focused on how things are rather than on how things could be. I found it a bit long and dry at times, but the background research has clearly been done, and there are numerous quotes throughout.

Title: This is Your Brain on Music: Understanding a Human Obsession
Author: Daniel J. Levitin
My Review: I wouldn't recommend this book: it was a slog to finish. I guess the audience is 'people who know nothing about music' and 'people who nothing about psychology', neither of which I fit into. The first two chapters are dedicated to music theory, which seemed gratuitous, and the rest of the book is bloated with uninteresting or not particularly relevant personal anecdotes. Perhaps it's because this is an under-researched field, but I felt this book was quite light on the actual science.

Title: Black Dogs
Author: Ian McEwan
My Review: The only McEwan novel I've read that I haven't enjoyed. This one felt quite disparate and just didn't really come together for me.

Title: A Dark-Adapted Eye
Author: Barbara Vine
My Review: Definitely not an 'unputdownable' book. A very complicated family tree and drawn-out portrait of a dysfunctional sibling relationship which culminates in murder.

Title: Joan of Arc
Author: Helen Castor
My Review: Superbly written and researched, but quite hard to get into at first. With any history book I find myself googling names and events along the way, but much more so with this book.

Title: A Demon in My View
Author: Ruth Rendell
My Review: My first Ruth Rendell. 3.5/5 for this one. Great writing and storytelling, but a very abrupt ending.

Title: Unnatural Causes
Author: Richard  Shepherd
My Review: A very unusual but very interesting memoir of a forensic pathologist.

Title: Bedlam: London and Its Mad
Author: Catharine Arnold
My Review: This was a slow-burner. The author likes tangents and quoting lengthily from historical sources.

Title: A Field Guide to Lies: Critical Thinking in the Information Age
Author: Daniel J. Levitin
My Review: Well written and accessible but there's little to learn here if you have had (postgraduate) training in research methods and statistics.

Title: Case Histories (Jackson Brodie #1)
Author: Kate Atkinson
My Review: Lots of mystery, but a bit far-fetched and silly in places.

Title: Why We Sleep: The New Science of Sleep and Dreams
Author: Matthew Walker
My Review: Sleep is something everyone does, so I think most people should find something interesting in this book. It's a good synthesis of current sleep science.

Title: Brighton Rock
Author: Graham Greene
My Review: A good story about the boozy and insalubrious gang culture of Brighton in the 1930s, but not well told. I wasn't a fan of the writing ('She sat there completely at her ease, her big breasts ready for any secrets') and I generally found I had to work hard to figure out what was going on.

Title: Prisoners of Geography: Ten Maps That Tell You Everything You Need To Know About Global Politics
Author: Tim Marshall
My Review: This book about geopolitics feels more political than it is geographical. It tries to cover a lot in a very short space and therefore perhaps predictably falls short.

Title: An Anthropologist on Mars: Seven Paradoxical Tales
Author: Oliver Sacks

Title: Where My Heart Used to Beat
Author: Sebastian Faulks
My Review: I was quite disappointed with this book. I was expecting the various strands of the story to come together in the end, but I don't really feel that they did.

Title: Persepolis: The Story of a Childhood and The Story of a Return

Title: The Sympathizer
Author: Viet Thanh Nguyen
My Review: I found this quite a slog to finish. The writing is very good but I just didn't get the story.

Title: Hello World: How Algorithms will Define our Future and Why We Should Learn To Live With It
Author: Hannah Fry
My Review: This is an enjoyable read - well-written and engaging, in an anecdotal style. It is slightly on the short side, and the conclusion is really where Fry touches on a possible collaboration or interaction between algorithms and humans rather than one being the overall ruler. I'd have liked this to be more fleshed out as it was very interesting. Overall, I would recommend this book!

Title: The Signal and the Noise: The Art and Science of Prediction
Author: Nate Silver
My Review: I lot of interesting stuff in here about the science of prediction, but Silver often uses tortuously detailed examples to get his points across (e.g. in the minutiae of baseball, poker, and stock markets). It takes some sticking with, but is worth it in parts.

Title: Small Island
Author: Andrea Levy
My Review: Overall, this book was enjoyable because it was told from the perspectives of different characters, but I think it could have easily been 100 pages shorter.

Title: Inside the Nudge Unit: How Small Changes Can Make a Big Difference
Author: David Halpern

Title: The Omnivore's Dilemma: A Natural History of Four Meals
Author: Michael Pollan
My Review: Overall, I did find this book a good read, but that was mainly due to the later chapters describing the author's experiences of hunting and gathering.

Title: Poverty Safari: Understanding the Anger of Britain's Underclass
Author: Darren McGarvey

Title: Wolf Hall (Thomas Cromwell, #1)
Author: Hilary Mantel
My Review: I didn't enjoy this very much. It's clear that Mantel is a good writer, but a lot of the book just felt like some kind of dream where I had no idea what was going on or who was talking to who. I'd also say that having some knowledge of the historical period is essential for reading this, because you won't learn it very clearly from the book itself.

Title: Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking
Author: Susan Cain

Title: The Sun King (Vintage Classics)
Author: Nancy Mitford
My Review: I read this after watching the BBC series Versailles, and I think this provided a good basis for accessing this book - in fact I quite struggled after about half way through, as the TV series stopped during Louis' young adulthood. In other words, this book definitely presumes background knowledge of the life and times of Louis XIV, so I wouldn't recommend it as a starting place.

Title: Kids These Days: Human Capital and the Making of Millennials
Author: Malcolm   Harris

Title: How To Be A Stoic: Ancient Wisdom for Modern Living
Author: Massimo Pigliucci

Title: The Road to Character
Author: David  Brooks
My Review:
I really wanted to enjoy this book but I would struggle to recommend it. Books about character are essentially collections of biographies, and Brooks has certainly done his homework on the people he discusses, but the writing is dry and staccato: this thing happened. And then another thing happened.
The book starts with an interesting look at the supposed rise of narcissism and introduces an interesting distinction between Adam I and Adam II values, but the chapters on individuals seemed to plod on at a snail's pace. To me, it really wasn't clear what the point of all of it was in the end.
Unfortunately the book has a heavy religious undertone, which really grated on me personally.

Author: Hans Rosling

Title: Einstein's Greatest Mistake: A Biography
Author: David Bodanis
My Review: This must have been a tricky book to write, because it is part-biography and part-theoretical physics primer. It is written in an accessible manner, although if you have read anything about Einstein's work before then there's not much new here. I was far more interested in the notes about his personal life and how he grappled between instinct and evidence. I think this part of the book could have been emphasised more.

My Review: In my opinion this book was excruciatingly dry, which is ironic for a book about pirates. Although clearly very thoroughly researched, it just didn't pull together into an interesting narrative. I found that it was full of seemingly isolated incidents with a lot of tedious details concerning exactly what kind of ship was involved, how many cannons it had, how many tonnes it could carry, and so on. I was disappointed and unfortunately wouldn't recommend this book to anyone.

Author: H.G. Wells

Title: The Selfish Gene
Author: Richard Dawkins
My Review: An interesting perspective on the role of the replicator (gene), and I like Dawkins' extension of this framework into meme theory. OK, so now I understand why related people carry out acts of altruism towards one another, but I feel totally in the dark about why two unrelated people would bother to help each other at all (did I miss this bit??)

Title: The Interpretation of Murder (Freud, #1)
Author: Jed Rubenfeld
My Review:
*contains spoilers*
Set against the backdrop of repressed pre-WWI America, the story is an application of psychoanalysis to a criminal investigation. Nora Acton, the stunning young debutante is seemingly traumatised by a disturbing attack on the eve of Freud's arrival in Manhattan. Dr Younger, an avid follower of the psychoanalytic method, carries out treatment under Freud's paternal guidance.
The story is long and convoluted and seems to be sewn together rather hastily at the climax of the novel.
The false pretense of Nora's trauma and symptomology serves to underline the absurdity and fallibility of Freud's school of thought. Dr Younger makes, what he thinks, are insightful and explanatory remarks throughout the investigation, only to figure out that her behaviour was a farce - an elaborate ploy to frame someone for murder.
The novel explores the fractious and strained relationship between Freud and his beleaguered disciple, Carl Jung.
